The film focuses on things that are less important and never touches on the impactful aspects.The ending is surprising, never expected it to end this way. Performances are good but character development did have some scope to improve. On technical levels like cinematography, score etc., the film does a fine job.Conclusion:
In finality, The Devil You Know had a potential and impactful plot but the screenplay couldn't bring out our emotions or make us care for any of the characters. It lacks a tighter script and proper execution.Rating:
5/10Follow Me On Instagram: M_Movie_Reviews.

4747.name: Bang Bang
4747.storyline: This is the first time ever a Flyboarding stunt was done in a Bollywood or Hollywood film. Hrithik Roshan became the first actor to do a flyboarding stunt in a film. Regarding the water sequences, the film's director Siddharth Anand revealed, "We can control the action we shoot on land, but while shooting at sea, you're at the mercy of the tide. Three days before the shoot, Hrithik started practicing the stunts for five-six hours daily. It took us eight days to shoot the sequences in water. For another water action sequence, Hrithik trained for four days, before the shooting. He learned to jet-ski with a speed boat pulling him along first. Then, an antiquated plane was brought in with an experienced pilot at the controls, so that it could be slowed down and speeded up at will."

4748.name: Into the Deep
4748.storyline: Referenced in Film Junk Podcast: Episode 867: Triangle of Sadness (2022)

4749.name: Into the Ashes
4749.storyline: The story was originally set in North Carolina.

4751.name: Bullet to Beijing
4751.storyline: As Michael Caine was 61 at the time of filming, it was decided to make Harry Palmer a retired secret agent.

4752.name: 15 Minutes
4752.storyline: Charlize Theron appeared for free, as a "thank you" to John Herzfeld for giving her the breakthrough role in 2 Days in the Valley (1996).

4753.name: Vadh
4753.storyline: Rathore Dada played by the actor in this movies is the Director Jaspal Singh Sandhu of this movie.

4754.name: Primal Rage
4754.storyline: Released a year before Nightmare Beach, which was also filmed in Florida, featured two actors from this film, and features a few of the same songs on the soundtrack. Umberto Lenzei was also involved with both films.

4755.name: Ransomed
4755.storyline: Ransomed is a Well balanced Thriller. This Well Go USA release is loosely based on real events that took place in the lead up the critically important 1988 Seoul Summer Olympics. When a previously kidnapped Korean Diplomat in Lebanon turns out to be alive a Korean Diplomatic office worker, played smartly by Ha Jung-woo, goes on a mission to deliver the ransom money and secure his release. When the mission gets dangerous and complicate he is forced to partner with an ex-pat, Korean taxi driver living in the area. That character is played by Ju Ji-hoon, and he is really, really great to watch. The film has elements of a spy thriller, action film, with the balance of the comedic aspects of an American "Buddy Film". There were times it reminded me of Escape to Mogadishu, which was more serious; at times of Argo; and at other times, Rush Hour. The end result of the film is one that is highly watchable and engaging. I highly recommend it. The acting, script, Direction, and cinematography are all very good. The supporting cast is very good in this, both on the Korean side, and inside of Beirut. Watch it in Korean, with English subititles.

4756.name: Godsend
4756.storyline: Robert De Niro had originally planned on merely providing a brief cameo for the film. However, after Director Nick Hamm heard De Niro would be interested in his project, he asked De Niro to participate in a few more scenes that were all filmed within a week. De Niro later regretted this because his name was "splashed over all the advertisements".

4757.name: The 4th Man
4757.storyline: Forty actors were tested for the part of Herman. Thom Hoffman got the part because he was the only actor bold enough to give Jeroen Krabbé a French kiss during his screentest.

4758.name: Lured
4758.storyline: The title was changed to "Personal Column" midway through the original U.S. theatrical release because staff at the Production Code Administration thought the word "lured" sounded too much like "lurid". Director Douglas Sirk felt the title change confused potential audiences and led to the film's box-office failure.

4759.name: Tales of Terror
4759.storyline: The "Black Cat" segment was recycled for "The Comedy of Terrors (1963)" (even the presence of a meddlesome cat). Many of the same actors appear in both films, only here Peter Lorre plays the drunk married to devoted Joyce Jameson, with Vincent Price introduced as the third member of the triangle; in "Comedy of Terrors" Price and Lorre exchange roles, and Jameson essentially repeats her performance. Not only that, but Price's line "What place is this?" from the "M. Valdemar" segment of "Tales of Terror" is recycled as a running gag for Basil Rathbone in "Comedy of Terrors".

4760.name: Crying Freeman
4760.storyline: Julie Condra and Mark Dacascos met and co-starred in this film, and then they married in real life.

4761.name: The Privilege
4761.storyline: When Finn Bergmann (Max Schimmelpfenning) arives at Eliska's greenhouse, you can see the exact same location used in the serie 'Dark'. In the serie 'Dark' it was property of the character Jürgen Obendorf

4763.name: Kinjite: Forbidden Subjects
4763.storyline: The last movie Charles Bronson made for Cannon Films.

4764.name: Looking Glass
4764.storyline: In interview with The Hollywood Reporter, Robin Tunney described Nicolas Cage as one of greatest actors ever, saying she never enjoyed working with someone as much as him.

4765.name: Adan
4765.storyline: Some what good movie both young actress are played very well. There is no way to live free women in the community always they treated them like a object.This movie contain lesbian loves scene only for mature audiences.But good movie once watchable.

4766.name: Prophecy
4766.storyline: Katahdin, the mutant bear-monster, is portrayed by 7"2' actor/stuntman Kevin Peter Hall who went on to play other memorable man-in-a-suit monsters of the 80s including the giant egg-headed alien in Without Warning (1980), the titular creature in Predator (1987) and Predator 2 (1990), and Bigfoot in Harry and the Hendersons (1989).

4768.name: One Day as a Lion
4768.storyline: Reunites Scott Caan and Taryn Manning. Both were in Hawaii Five O (2010)

4769.name: Message from the King
4769.storyline: Chadwick Boseman stated in an interview that he based his accent he uses for the Marvel character Black Panther from a film he was working on where he played a man from South Africa. This is the film to which he was referring.

4770.name: Animal
4770.storyline: Thorsten Kaye lost his voice for one day after breathing toxic smoke from a flare.

4771.name: Raid
4771.storyline: A scene showed where the actress playing Indira Gandhi was walking in the compound of her house where two kids were shown playing. These kids are referred to as Rahul and Priyanka Gandhi, the children of Sonia Gandhi.

4772.name: Brain Dead
4772.storyline: Dr. Rex Martin mentioned that he went to "Miskatonic University", the college where Re-Animator (1985) took place. Miskatonic University is supposedly located in Arkham, Massachusetts, a fictional town created by H.P. Lovecraft.

4773.name: The Child Remains
4773.storyline: Loosely based on The Ideal Maternity Home (IMH), located in Chester, Nova Scotia. The IMH, which was a maternity home, for unwed mothers, operated from 1928 until 1947 by William Peach Young, a chiropractor and unordained minister of the Seventh-day Adventist Church, and his wife Lila Gladys Young, a midwife, although she advertised herself as an obstetrician. The business was eventually shut down by the government.

4775.name: Every Secret Thing
4775.storyline: In (2010), Frances McDormand originally approached friend and filmmaker, Nicole Holofcener to direct the movie, as well as adapt the book into a screenplay. While Nicole Holofcener doesn't direct, she is still attached to the film and receives a writing credit and Frances McDormand is given a producer credit.

4776.name: Guns, Girls and Gambling
4776.storyline: The Blonde quotes Edgar Allen Poe in every scene. She quotes from "The Raven" and from "Annabelle Lee."

4777.name: Laid to Rest
4777.storyline: Lead actress Bobbi Sue Luther and director Robert Hall used to be married.

4778.name: The Principal
4778.storyline: Northgate High School in Walnut Creek, California was used as the filming location for the affluent school at the beginning of the film. Many students and teachers served as extras. After filming of the scenes were finished, Jim Belushi posed for a picture with everyone from that school. The picture has been printed in the yearbook from that year since.

4779.name: The Legend of Maula Jatt
4779.storyline: The legend of Maula Jatt is Pakistani cinema's most expensive film till date

4780.name: Styx
4780.storyline: Rike's yacht, Asa Gray, is named after an eminent 19th century American botanist.

4781.name: The Collini Case
4781.storyline: The book and movie are based losely on a similar real case (Friedrich Engel), without spoiling too much for new viewers.

4782.name: The Last Days of American Crime
4782.storyline: Sam Worthington was originally attached to star in the film. F. Gary Gray and Anthony Mandler were set to direct.

4783.name: Carter
4783.storyline: Joo Won put on a total of seven kilograms (approximately 15.4 pounds) of muscle weight. He also went through three to four months of intensive training on performing stunts and action scenes, including car chases and handling motorcycles.

4784.name: Shanghai
4784.storyline: The project was set to roll in early 2008 in China, but the authorities blocked the shoot just a few weeks before production was set to begin. China's exit meant walking away from sets that had been built, at a cost of three million dollars. The Weinstein Company shifted the shoot to London and Thailand, where sets have been built re-creating Shanghai's old colonial architecture.

4785.name: Indictment: The McMartin Trial
4785.storyline: James Woods filmed his role as Lester Diamond in Casino (1995) on a weekend break from shooting this film.

4786.name: Death Hunt
4786.storyline: Charles Bronson once said of his Albert Johnson character in this movie: "There are two schools of thought about the characters . . . Some believe the man [Albert Johnson] was a criminal. Others believe, as I do, that he was innocent of any wrongdoing. We decided to show him as a man who was a victim of someone else's need to perform violence. In trying to protect himself against an unprovoked attack, he was forced to kill one of his assailants."

4787.name: Vanquish
4787.storyline: Victoria's motorcycle is a Harley-Davidson Livewire.

4788.name: Asylum
4788.storyline: Credited as an executive producer on the film, Natasha Richardson denied this allowed her to dictate proceedings - even when it came to the numerous sex scenes. "I'm an actress and I'm working for the director," she said. "David Mackenzie made it clear he wanted it to be as real as possible. He didn't want any restrictions whatsoever, and he asked me if I was comfortable with that. I said yes, and I was, because I knew that for this movie to work it had to be very hot and very real, and it wasn't going to be a case of doing it Hollywood all covered with a nice little sheet. So I signed up for that, and I thought it was right, but it didn't make it any easier to do. What's in the movie compared to what we shot is the tip of the iceberg."

4789.name: Untitled Fast & Furious Film
4789.storyline: Dwayne Johnson made his return to the Fast and Furious franchise in Fast X after missing out on Fast 9

4790.name: Raado
4790.storyline: Just a wow movie. Screen play, direction, editing, music, story, lineup, etc. Etc. Etc. Amazing at all levels. Never watched a Gujarati movie like this before.

4791.name: [REC] 4: Apocalypse
4791.storyline: If you watch REC (2007), [Rec]² (2009) and this film back to back without watching the end credits, the three movies would play out as one entire sequence of events.

4792.name: Semper Fi
4792.storyline: When the project was announced, Sam Claflin was cast in the lead role. He later dropped out due to scheduling conflicts and was replaced by Jai Courtney.

4793.name: The Ninth Configuration
4793.storyline: Joe Spinell's character of "Spinell", a patient at the castle-hospital, was not in the novel nor the original script. Spinell had begged writer and director William Peter Blatty, a close friend of his, to cast him in a small role as the sidekick to Jason Miller's character of Lieutenant Reno. Since there was no part for Spinell in the movie, his character was given the same last name. Nearly all of Spinell's dialogue was ad-libbed.

4794.name: The Betrayed
4794.storyline: Melissa George and Oded Fehr were on Charmed (1998) but not in the same episodes. Oded Fehr played a very powerful , Zankou, while Melissa George played a Valkyrie, Freyja.

4795.name: The Baker
4795.storyline: "This film is very special to me," says Ron Perlman. "It pits a cold, dark, explosively violent world, filled with unspeakable histories, against the gravitational forces of long forgotten loved ones, making its reluctant hero do anything to protect the innocent. Anything! (7/19/2023)"

4796.name: Forbidden Empire
4796.storyline: Despite the fact that this was the highest grossing Russian movie of 2014, it did not get a cinematic release in most other countries. A lawsuit between two of the film's production companies over budget issues caused a significant production delay, after which, a distribution deal for the international market was cancelled. As a result, the movie was released direct-to-DVD in many big markets such as the U.S. and the U.K.

4797.name: Game Changer
4797.storyline: The film marks director Shankar's first direct film in the Telugu language after years of releasing his tamil films dubbed into telugu. Director Shankar owes the success of the Telugu dubbed versions to producer, A.M. Rathnam. Rathnam's association with Shankar dates back to buying Shankar's first 2 films for their Telugu dubbed release. It was the successes of these two films that led to Rathnam to produce Indian & later his debut Hindi film, Nayak.

4798.name: Ice Cream Man
4798.storyline: Clint Howard screamed and yelled at the top of his lungs while driving in a car every day to the set in order to have a more gravelly voice for his role as Gregory.

4799.name: UFO
4799.storyline: Loosely based on events of November 7, 2006, when multiple eyewitnesses at Chicago O'Hare International Airport (including control tower personnel and flight crews) reported an Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon (UAP) hovering over Gate C17.

4800.name: Trash
4800.storyline: It is based on the 2010 novel by Andy Mulligan.

4801.name: Christmas Carol
4801.storyline:
I like Korean movies as they do not put sex and romance scenes which have nothing to do with the plot
Bht this plot is weak:The description states he is going to the juvi.But the at the beginning the age is given as 28. With 28 they are not sent to a juvi.I like Korean movies as they do not put sex and romance scenes which have nothing to do with the plot
Bht this plot is weak:The description states he is going to the juvi.But the at the beginning the age is given as 28. With 28 they are not sent to a juvi.I like Korean movies as they do not put sex and romance scenes which have nothing to do with the plot
Bht this plot is weak:The description states he is going to the juvi.But the at the beginning the age is given as 28. With 28 they are not sent to a juvi.

4802.name: Wildland
4802.storyline: The Danish title means "Flesh and Blood".

4803.name: Staying on Top
4803.storyline: Though not explicitly shown, Danny Pape and Angela Nicholas had unsimulated sex in their sex scene.

4805.name: An Acceptable Loss
4805.storyline: Tika Sumpter has played characters who have close political ties to the fictional/non fictional Presidents, including the one played by Jamie Lee Curtis in this film. She also played Michelle Obama in the film Southside and Me (2016). Also, her recurring character (Candice) on the hit TV series "The Have and The Have Nots" has a relationship with the fictional president elect.

4806.name: The Manhattan Project
4806.storyline: The kids with science projects in the background of the science fair scenes were actual NYC middle school students with real science projects that were submitted to the NYC borough-wide science fair. These scenes were filmed over a three-day period at the Penta Hotel in NYC on 33rd St.

4807.name: The Lover in the Attic: A True Story
4807.storyline: Dolly has a poster advertising Puccini's last opera, "Turandot," on the wall of her home in Hollywood. "Turandot" is an opera about a Chinese princess who asks any man who wants to marry her to answer three riddles. If they fail the test, she has them executed and their heads mounted on pikes outside her palace. She's finally outwitted by the hero, Tatar Prince Calaf, who answers her riddles and ultimately marries her.

4808.name: The Tall Man
4808.storyline: Inspired by the legend of Slenderman, which itself eventually spawned its own film, Slender Man (2018).

4809.name: Frontera
4809.storyline: Cameo: Director/writer Michael Berry, his wife and daughter. Family that got their house broke into and their truck stolen.

4810.name: Maniac Cop 2
4810.storyline: Bruce Campbell has jokingly stated at conventions that he does not like being reminded of or asked questions about this film, as he was going through a messy divorce during filming. Violators of the taboo will quickly find themselves on the receiving end of Campbell's legendarily ruthless razor wit. This has led to convention-goers deliberately bringing up the film in order to have the "honor" of being insulted by him.

4811.name: They Look Like People
4811.storyline: This is the first feature length film written and directed by Perry Blackshear.

4812.name: Demonte Colony 2
4812.storyline: Who is giving this movie 8-9 stars.... Everything about this movie is bad...the movie is jumping all around the place....the acting is bad.... Especially from the female. Lead.... She is so bad...Never in my lifetime of watching a movie i wanted a lead character to just die so the movie can end.... Or maybe the director of the movie was bad.... Idk... The horror in this movie is irritating & will make you fall asleep....the plot feels forced. The cgi is bad... The music is bad... Editing is bad.... Some practical effects and set design are good.. But thats about it...Also why this movies is registered under horror/comedy... Where is the comedy aspect here...

4813.name: The New Daughter
4813.storyline: Based on a short story from the horror anthology "Nocturnes" by John Connolly.

4814.name: Flight of the Intruder
4814.storyline: Near the end of the film, the phonetic alphabet phrase "Alpha Mike Foxtrot" is spoken over the radio. This is an abbreviation for "Adios Motherfucker," which is said over the radio by downed aircrews, when they know death or capture is imminent.

4815.name: Vanishing Waves
4815.storyline: Vanishing Waves (Opening Credits)Arranged By Martin HederosMusic By Peter Von Poehl

4816.name: Captain Alatriste: The Spanish Musketeer
4816.storyline: At a cost of 24 million Euros, this was the most expensive Spanish film ever made until Agora (2009) surpassed it. Director Agustín Díaz Yanes called that amount enough for 'a European super-production and an American rubbish-production'.

4817.name: Kiss of Death
4817.storyline: Originally, Patricia Morison played Victor Mature's wife, who is attacked and raped by a gangster who is supposed to be watching out for her while Mature is in prison. Afterwards, she commits suicide by sticking her head in the kitchen oven and turning on the gas. Both scenes were cut from the original print at the insistence of the censors, who wanted no depiction of either a rape or a suicide, so she does not appear in the film at all. Mention is made later in the film about Mature's wife's suicide and an obscure reference is made by Nettie that the unseen gangster Rizzo contributed to the wife's downfall.

4818.name: Mesrine: Killer Instinct
4818.storyline: The filming of this and Mesrine: Public Enemy No. 1 (2008), which lasted nine straight months, was done in reverse chronological order so that Vincent Cassel could progressively lose the weight he gained in preparation of the role, as Cassel knew he couldn't gain weight while filming.

4819.name: The Last Manhunt
4819.storyline: The Last Manhunt (2022) is a re-telling of the story of the hunt for Willie Boy, attempted once before in the film Tell Them Willie Boy Is Here (1969) starring Robert Blake, Robert Redford and Katharine Ross based on the novel by Harry Lawton based on a Paiute legend.

4820.name: The Haunting of Sharon Tate
4820.storyline: Actress Sharon Tate's sister Debra Tate, has stated she does not support the Hilary Duff movie about her sister's life, Debra said, "It's been exploitative since day one. It's been the case since the media went crazy and has perpetuated mistruths making things even more salacious. It's now morphed into something that is more fictionalized than truth at this point. To celebrate the killers and the darkest portion of society as being sexy or acceptable in any way, shape or form is just perpetuating the worst of our society. I am vehemently opposed to anything that does that. I've been dealing with this for 50 years now. We need to stop this, and I intend to help the family behind the NoNotoriety anyway I can to help make this a national movement."

4821.name: Mr. Bachchan
4821.storyline: The film opened theatrically on the same date as Double Ismart (2024) starring Ram Pothineni, who was set to collaborate with Harish Shankar. The project was shelved after both the films received negative reviews and flopped at the box office.

4822.name: Scream for Help
4822.storyline: This movie was to have been the third collaboration between writer Tom Holland and director Richard Franklin (following Psycho II (1983) & Cloak & Dagger (1984)) but with his career on the rise, Franklin ultimately decided it would be unwise to helm such a low-budget film.

4823.name: Jackdaw
4823.storyline: Reunites Jenna Coleman and Oliver Jackson-Cohen who have recently started in the Amazon Prime thriller Wilderness.

4824.name: Sharknado 3: Oh Hell No!
4824.storyline: (at around 26 mins) During the first view of the inside of the armored RV, license plates can be seen on the wall, including the plate from Jaws (1975).

4825.name: Hard Home
4825.storyline: A grieving mother who is quite adept at making high tech smart home systems, lures the serial killer who brutally murdered her only daughter into a smart home labyrinth of various tortures and tests to torment and anger the killer as he tries to escape and survive at the same time. It does not seem to be the good idea to capture a serial killer of this magnitude and play games with him, but given the system tends to not give real justice in these kind of cases, you tend to agree with the mothers choice to take things into her own hands. She is totally obsessed and focuses her whole life into this one goal of punishing the killer. She's si obsessed that she does make a few terrible mistakes. Lots of cool tech, suspense, a bit of terror and tongue cutting, not for the squeamish or kiddos. No questionable content, nudity or foul language, entertaining suspenseful movie. Enjoy.

4826.name: What Have You Done to Solange?
4826.storyline: Mindful of the American aversion to dubbed foreign films, the production team decided that the shooting would be exclusively made in English language despite the accent of the actors. Consequently the English looping coincided so well with the lip movements of the actors that no one in the U.S. noticed the film was dubbed.

4827.name: Backtrace
4827.storyline: Casting was done by Emmett Furla who engaged with various "Investor Actors" to finance the film.

4828.name: Batman: Gotham by Gaslight
4828.storyline: Batman: Gotham by Gaslight, originally published in 1989, is considered to be DC Comics' first Elseworlds story. According to the DC editorial copy, "in ELSEWORLDS, heroes are taken from their usual settings and put into strange times and places--some that have existed, and others that can't, couldn't, or shouldn't exist."

4829.name: Nightmare Cinema
4829.storyline: Orson Chaplin, who plays the murderous carjacker Jenkins, (In the "Dead" segment by Mick Garris) is a direct grandson of Charlie Chaplin.

4830.name: Ritual
4830.storyline: Sequel to The Treatment (2014) , based upon the novel Ritual by Mo Hayder.

4832.name: Return to Return to Nuke 'Em High Aka Vol. 2
4832.storyline: The budget for the post production of the film had to be funded by a Kickstarter campaign in order cover the cost of the sound mixing, color correction, editing, special effects, mastering, and other methods needed to finish the film.

4833.name: Alone at Night
4833.storyline: Pizza Guy's jacket appears to be the same jacket from Home Alone. Little Nero's Pizza. An homage to Home Alone starting with knocking over the statue on arriving.

4835.name: Death Machine
4835.storyline: Yutani's declaration of "Shouryuken" before opening fire is a reference to the video game Street Fighter 2. It literally translates as "Rising Dragon Fist", and is the battle cry attached to an unstoppable uppercut move.

4836.name: Stolen
4836.storyline: Nicolas Cage's character picks up a stuffed animal as a gift for his daughter. He also does this in Con Air (1997), which is also directed by Simon West.

4837.name: The Collected
4837.storyline: Director Marcus Dunstan confirmed in an interview on July 16th, 2024 that the third installment is officially underway after 5 years in development hell.

4838.name: 1BR
4838.storyline: The first word of the name of the apartment complex, "Asilo," means "Asylum" in Spanish.

4840.name: The Activated Man
4840.storyline: Anyone who has lost someone they love (especially a dog) will relate specifically to this film. A darkness that follows can be very real. The Activated Man dives deep into real and raw emotion and connection. Amazing performances from Tony Todd and Kane Hodder. And, a truly frightening and ominous antagonist. Family connections and betrayal. Production value of a big studio film. Special and visual effects that look like ILM. Atmospheric, suspenseful, and moments of honest humanity. The Activated Man is a journey through a horrific event and family toxicity. Horror blended with action and fantasy.

4841.name: Electra Glide in Blue
4841.storyline: First-time director James William Guercio wanted Conrad L. Hall to photograph this film, but Hall's salary was more than was budgeted for a cinematographer. Guercio reduced his own salary to $1.00 so he could secure Hall as the cinematographer.

4842.name: Dark Windows
4842.storyline: Peter: Wanna hear a joke?Tilly: Not really.Peter: That's okay. I was gonna do a dead baby joke, but I decided to abort.

4843.name: Mother of Tears
4843.storyline: Dario Argento reportedly offered the title role to Ania Pieroni, who had briefly played the same character in Inferno (1980). The actress declined the offer, on account of her age and having been retired since 1985.

4844.name: I Still See You
4844.storyline: Film is based on the 2012 novel "Break My Heart 1,000 Times", written by Daniel Waters.

4845.name: Python
4845.storyline: A full-scale python head was constructed and used during filming, but never once is seen on-screen in the final cut.

4846.name: Celia
4846.storyline: Detective Bruce Lester (Larry) calls on the help of friend Hy Hazell (Celia) to help him discover what has happened to Elsie Wagstaff (Aunt Nora). She goes undercover as a housemaid in the country house in which Wagstaff is hidden away and young husband John Bailey (Lester) seems to be scheming up some evilness.It's a short film and it keeps you watching for the duration. There are no surprises and Hy Hazell carries the film along with her enthusiasm. It takes a bit of a while to get going and it's ok while it lasts. It's a comedy so there is never really any real threat to anyone's life although the film does succeed in delivering some tension, eg, hiding in the bedroom. Of more interest is reading about Hy Hazell and the way she died in real life. She choked on a steak whilst eating at a Westminster restaurant at the age of 50. I want to know more. It's more interesting than the film.

4847.name: Death in the Cul-De-Sac
4847.storyline: Loved this well made and well written soapy and suspenseful thriller. All is not as it seems in this idyllic neighborhood where the local moms gather for their club. "Loyalty" is not only expected but dangerously enforced. This fun and engrossing film will keep you guessing until the very end. Peppered with crisp and at times deliciously shady dialogue, the actresses playing both the possibly wicked and possibly innocent archetypes are on point. Characters are fleshed out nicely which allows us to relate to or revile them. I think all of us have encountered these personalities which make the proceedings all the more delightful. Solid performances, well written twists and turns and really beautiful cinematography make this a standout in the genre. Highly recommended.

4848.name: DoUtDes
4848.storyline: The peacock chair that Emanuelle sits on became famous due to its appearance in the 1970's risque film Emmanuelle.

4849.name: Flame & Citron
4849.storyline: With a budget over $10 million, this is one of the most expensive movies made in Denmark.

4850.name: Gossip
4850.storyline: The university that the students attend was also used as the setting for several other films including Urban Legend (1998) and The Skulls (2000). Coincidentally all three films starred Joshua Jackson.

4851.name: The Night of the Generals
4851.storyline: Because Peter O'Toole and Omar Sharif were being held to contracts signed several years earlier, when they were less famous, they both had to accept smaller fees than one would expect, given how famous they were when this movie was made early in 1966. Neither was very happy with this situation, but they took care to claim the lavish living expenses to which they were entitled.

4852.name: So Young, So Lovely, So Vicious...
4852.storyline: JB is their brand of choice for scotch, natch. Marlboro cigarettes.

4853.name: The Final
4853.storyline: The "guards" in the woods are actually 3 other outcasts from school (seen on the school stairs and in the cafeteria). They are not the same outcasts as the ones in the party house, even though they are wearing the same costumes. This was meant to confuse the police when it was all over. Due to time constraints, this subplot was cut from the film, and is only subtly explained.

4854.name: Day Drinker
4854.storyline: Project notes, plot, and industry news

4855.name: The Pact
4855.storyline: When Annie searches the Internet for Judas, she comes across the fictional "Judas-The San Pedro Killer." However, the summarized murders attributed to Judas are in fact the victims (including actual names and locations) of the Zodiac Killer.

4856.name: After Dark
4856.storyline:
Oh boy this was bad, really bad.
Firstly the acting, dreadful. It's as easy as that. The budget was zero, the Tory line would have been better if there was tension in the film, there was none.
Okay I would say from a guy's point of view the girls were nice.
The script itself has to be blamed as well, it was awful, I could have done a better one, check anyone could have.
Don't bother with this travesty, I would give it zero stars.
But I have given one star for effort and the other star for the girls.

4858.name: The Crimson Kimono
4858.storyline: Only one Nisei received a Medal of Honor in the Korean War: Hiroshi H Miyamura. None of the 21 Nisei who received their Medal of Honor awards for heroism in World War II had received them by the time the film was made. The awards were granted in 2000, after a study revealed discrimination that caused them to be overlooked during the war.

4859.name: Disaster on the Coastliner
4859.storyline: The television that the terrorist (Paul Smith) was using to monitor the news broadcast in the locomotive, was a Sharp Sidekick, Model 3T-50B made in 1978. This television was only available in black and white. The picture displayed on the unit in the film, was a color image.

4860.name: Gods of the Deep
4860.storyline: The film Underwater (2020) similarly dealt with a team of humans encountering a gigantic Chthulu-like monster on the ocean floor, only with a considerably larger budget. Both films owe major debts to H.P. Lovecraft, but do not credit him.

4861.name: Dangerous Game: The Legacy Murders
4861.storyline: The actors who portray the characters "Alec" and "Joy" were both in Grey's Anatomy (2005). Will Sasso (Alec) was the engineer whose legs got stuck in the elevator during the storm, and Skyler Shaye (Joy) was Katie Bryce.

4862.name: Fan
4862.storyline: The first movie ever to be shot in the venue of Madam Tussaud's in London.

4863.name: Lolly-Madonna XXX
4863.storyline: Based on the 1969 novel, "The Lolly Madonna War," by Sue Grafton, author of the popular "alphabet mysteries" featuring hard-boiled female Private Investigator Kinsey Millhone. The twelfth installment, "'L' is for Lawless," was published in the United States in 1995.

4864.name: Dead Heat
4864.storyline: The building used for Dante Pharmaceuticals is also the set of the movie Bio-Dome 8 years later.

4865.name: The Den
4865.storyline: Bill Oberst, Jr., the uncredited actor who plays Skeeter, is the same actor from the viral campaign "Take the Lollipop", which spread awareness of the dangers of online stalking.

4866.name: Duel at Diablo
4866.storyline: James Garner's first western since leaving Maverick (1957) and Sidney Poitier's first theatrical western.

4867.name: The Seven-Per-Cent Solution
4867.storyline: The title of the movie refers to the drug Sherlock Holmes is abusing. He injects himself with a solution of seven percent cocaine and ninety-three percent saline solution.

4868.name: Futureworld
4868.storyline: The tram to Futureworld is the tunnel train at Houston Intercontinental Airport (IAH), now George Bush Intercontinental Airport, in Houston, TX.

4869.name: Fatherland
4869.storyline: The pompous buildings in post-war Berlin were based on actual plans by Albert Speer, Adolf Hitler's favorite architect and secretary of armaments. Amongst several other landmarks we see a huge dome (the Reichhalle) a Triumph Arch, an Olympic Stadium, and the Reich's Chancellorship. Only the Stadium and the Chancellorship were actually built, but the later was wrecked by bombings and finally looted and demolished by the Red Army. The rest of them were never built, and constructions like the Arch and the Dome were so massive, that architects were unsure of their viability, until recent computer-based simulation have stated that Speer's calculations were correct, and had Hitler won the war, Berlin would have pretty much looked as the movie shows. Interestingly, the movie also portrays Berlin as bleak and gray. In the book, March describes the city looking like this from the never ending construction projects.

4870.name: Julie Darling
4870.storyline: Cindy Girling (Irene) played the character Wendy in Meatballs(1979), Isabelle Mejias (Julie) would go on to play Wendy in Meatballs III: Summer Job(1986).

4871.name: In Hell
4871.storyline: Lawrence Taylor's character is named 451, a reference to Ray Bradbury's novel Fahrenheit 451.

4872.name: The Enemy Below
4872.storyline: One of the technical consultants working on this movie was Albert Beck, a former German U-boat submariner, who advised on the submarine scenes.

4873.name: Gantz: O
4873.storyline: The "O" in the title refers to Osaka, the primary location for the story, which is based on the "Osaka" arc of the original manga.

4875.name: Lonely Hearts
4875.storyline: The director's grandfather was Elmer C. Robinson, the cop who investigated the Lonely Hearts murders. The director dedicated the film to his grandfather.

4876.name: Instinct
4876.storyline: The Winston gorillas in were so authentic, few people viewing the film ever realized that the animals were not real. "One of the greatest compliments I got from a friend," said Paul Mejias, "was when he said: 'I saw Instinct. Which were the real gorillas and which were yours?' That said it all." "The combination of the art and technology that went into our gorilla heads and suits," added Stan Winston, "the gorilla performances of the actors in those suits, and the fact that they were shot in a natural environment resulted in some of the best gorilla work I've ever seen. We'd had to go through a learning curve on Congo. But with Instinct, we nailed it."

4877.name: Dear Jassi
4877.storyline: Dear Jassi Movie depicts the subtleties of Indian culture and traditions wonderfully. It celebrates the culture's brightness and complexity while also diving into the issues that the younger generation faces. It finds a fine mix between comedic moments and serious social themes. This combination results in a well-rounded film that appeals to a wide spectrum of audiences and inspires crucial discussions. Dear Jassi Movie's direction is commendable, as the filmmaker skilfully ties together many narrative lines. The rhythm is well-balanced, with opportunities for meditation and introspection. Dear Jassi Movie's screenplay is exceptionally well-crafted, with a wonderful blend of drama, romance, and humor.

4879.name: The Day of the Dolphin
4879.storyline: The trained dolphins who played Alpha and Beta were named Buck (for screenwriter Buck Henry) and Ginger (for dancer Ginger Rogers). On the next to the last day of filming, when their parts were done, they escaped and never returned.

4880.name: Rogue City
4880.storyline: Inspired by the Marseille bar massacre on 3 October 1978 when ten people were murdered in the Bar du Téléphone in Marseille, France. The event also inspired Le bar du téléphone (1980).

4881.name: Balestra
4881.storyline: Tessa Thompson was originally cast in the lead role but ended up dropping out due to scheduling conflicts.

4882.name: The Isle
4882.storyline: This fell foul of the British Board of Film Classification who demanded cuts, not because of the scene where a metal object is inserted into a vagina but of cruelty to fish, which director Kim Ki-duk admitted was genuine.

4883.name: Art of Love
4883.storyline: I love Li's performance from her first scene in the movie! She is so stunning and the way she handles the conflict makes me very emotional related! The way she looks at the professor does not only seduce him but also sizzle me. Don't understand why other reviews are so critical. Yes it is a old style romance movie. But sometimes when people are stressed out, people just want to watch this kind of old fashioned romance movie to relax and to be healed. The art of love has successfully achieved this goal, especially by Li's excellent performance. I will definitely recommend this move to my friends and watch it again on a Friday night!

4884.name: Zero Effect
4884.storyline: Jake Kasdan wrote the part of Daryl Zero specifically for Bill Pullman after meeting the actor on the set of The Accidental Tourist (1988), directed by his father, Lawrence Kasdan.

4885.name: Dementia 13
4885.storyline: Francis Ford Coppola was assisting Roger Corman on the set of The Young Racers (1963) in Ireland. Corman allowed Coppola to use the same set, crew, and actors Luana Anders, William Campbell, and Patrick Magee for this film if he could shoot around the shooting schedule of Corman's film.

4886.name: Desert Fury
4886.storyline: The wood paneled burgundy convertible driven by Paula in the film is a 1946 Chrysler New Yorker Town and Country. These cruisers weighed over two tons, and were 218 inches long, 15 inches longer than the longest sedans produced today. The Town & Country cars were virtually coachbuilt inside and out, and their prices reflected this slow method of production. Despite prices that rivaled Cadillac-a base of $2,725 in 1946, some 8,368 New Yorker Town & Country convertibles found willing buyers during those three years.

4887.name: Vanishing on 7th Street
4887.storyline: The cast members would jog in place in between takes in order to maintain a proper level of intensity that was required for their characters.

4888.name: The Caller
4888.storyline: The original ending to the film featured a young couple being shown around the apartment after Mary has moved. The final shot focused on the telephone ringing ominously. The ending that was eventually used was actually to be the second-to-last scene in the film.

4889.name: Adagio
4889.storyline: The rap song at the beginning of the movie relates what will happen in it, and also the source of the drama ("if money is the root of all evil, why do you spend it on nothing?").

4890.name: Kiss of Death
4890.storyline: The club featured in the film was actually a small business office building next to McDonald's in Queens, New York that was completely converted to the look in the film by production designer Mel Bourne. It is now abandoned, and remains unused to this day.

4891.name: Good People
4891.storyline: James Franco and Kate Hudson share the same birthday (April 19th) but were born in a full year apart from each other. Franco was born in 1978 and Hudson was born in 1979.

4892.name: Hamlet
4892.storyline: At 29, Ethan Hawke is the youngest actor to play Hamlet on film. He is also close to the age Hamlet is supposed to be in the original text, which is 30.

4893.name: The Teacher
4893.storyline: Angel Tompkins was offered percentage points on the profits for this film, but turned it down in favor of payment up front.

4894.name: The Nightcomers
4894.storyline: Marlon Brando once approached director Michael Winner on the set and requested that the script be rewritten, to which Winner responded: "Marlon, you've had the script for nine months, we haven't got time to redo the whole bloody thing now, thank you very much. It's a low budget film and you had a great deal of time to make this speech. It's no good making it standing in a country lane in Cambridgeshire with Francis Ford Coppola behind the barrier with the crowd watching. This is not the time dear - I'm terribly sorry".

4895.name: Real
4895.storyline: So, why two out of ten stars for this movie? Because the performances were really good so I had to give them that.However, the story was ... hmm ... complicated. It didn't make sense most of the time and when it finally did, it just wasn't worth the two hours plus that were wasted watching it. Some of the mature scenes were, I guess, there to make it more edgy, but, for real, there were just unnecessary. The action scenes were okay and the visuals really nice, but they seemed to focus more on them than the story, which was just thinly spread through this lengthy film.So, overall, two out of ten.

4896.name: Hellhole
4896.storyline: The part of Dr. Fletcher was originally to be played by Britt Ekland but the role was ultimately cast with Mary Woronov.

4897.name: Goodbye Lover
4897.storyline: Last Regency Enterprises film distributed by Warner Bros. until The Fountain (2006).

4898.name: Taste the Blood of Dracula
4898.storyline: The film was originally not going to feature Dracula at all, much like The Brides of Dracula (1960), due to Christopher Lee becoming increasingly reluctant to reprise the role and the producers not expecting to be able to convince him to do so. Lee's increasing salary demands were also a factor. Ralph Bates would have played the lead. The script was re-written to include Dracula after the producers were finally able to coax Lee back to the role after "Warner-Seven Arts" refused to back this movie without the actor's participation.

4899.name: Cold Blood
4899.storyline: When the bodyguard gets the text telling him not to 'loose' her again, the phone displays the network provider as Kyivstar, a Ukrainian telecommunications company, despite supposedly being in Washington State.

4900.name: Tulpa: Demon of Desire
4900.storyline: Italian censorship visa # 107436 delivered on 12 June 2013.

4901.name: Voice from the Stone
4901.storyline: When the project was first announced, Maggie Gyllenhaal was attached to the lead role. Emilia Clarke eventually replaced the actress after the movie was stuck in development.

4902.name: The Boston Strangler
4902.storyline: Tony Curtis generally was considered too old to play Albert DeSalvo despite being only six years older than DeSalvo. At the times of the murders, DeSalvo was only in his early thirties.

4903.name: The Dead Girl
4903.storyline: The film cast includes two Oscar winners: Mary Steenburgen and Marcia Gay Harden; and five Oscar nominees: Piper Laurie, Toni Collette, Josh Brolin, James Franco and Bruce Davison.

4904.name: Page Eight
4904.storyline: Bill Nighy once said of playing his MI5 spy character, "I'd play Johnny Worricker for the rest of my life! I'd be perfectly happy as long as they keep me in a good suit."

4905.name: Lake Placid 3
4905.storyline: Movie debut -- and first nude scenes -- of British actress Roxanne Carrion (aka Roxanne Pallet), known for her role in the British soap opera Emmerdale Farm (1972).

4906.name: Mata Hari
4906.storyline: The genealogy of the Mata Hari character was half-Dutch and half-Javanese. Actress Sylvia Kristel playing her was actually in real-life of Dutch lineage herself having come from Holland. Kristel was born in Utrecht in the Netherlands whereas the real-life Mata Hari was born in Leeuwarden, Holland.

4907.name: Isolation
4907.storyline: In the beginning the man protecting his property shoots a nail from a nail gun that should be attached to an air compressor but is not

4908.name: The Trust
4908.storyline: Jerry Lewis joined the project at the insistence of Nicolas Cage; the two have been friends for years. Lewis, however, has less than one minute of screen time.

4909.name: London After Midnight
4909.storyline: It is believed that this film existed until 1967. Inventory records indicated that the only remaining print was being stored in MGM's vault #7 which was destroyed by fire in 1967. By that time, all other elements had been destroyed or were missing.

4910.name: Wonder Women
4910.storyline: The man who gets hit by a car and knocked down to the ground during the car chase sequence wasn't a planned stunt. Fortunately, the man didn't get hurt.

4911.name: In the Cold of the Night
4911.storyline: Filmed back to back with Hired to Kill (1990).

4912.name: The Last Sharknado: It's About Time
4912.storyline: (at around 1h 6 mins) When he travels to the future, Fin says "I wonder what Deadpool movie we're on." In Deadpool 2 (2018), while fighting Deadpool, Cable says "The name's Cable, I'm from the future." Deadpool replies "Oh, you're from the future? I have 3 questions then. (1) is Dubstep still a thing? (2) Which Sharknado are we on?"

4914.name: Revenge of the Ninja
4914.storyline: The film was originally to be shot in Los Angeles, but the necessary permits, police protection, fire marshals and myriad logistics fees would be taking up a bigger and bigger part of the film's budget. The Utah Film Commission was trying to get Cannon Films to start producing films in their state and a representative promised no permits, location fees or union deals as well as lower salaries for local crews. The commission's assurances persuaded Cannon to switch filming to Salt Lake City.

4915.name: Never Talk to Strangers
4915.storyline: Raúl Ruiz was originally slated to direct this film.

4916.name: Skiptrace
4916.storyline: Seann William Scott was set to star as Connor Watts but dropped out. Johnny Knoxville replaced him.

4918.name: Cade: The Tortured Crossing
4918.storyline: Neil Breen's first official film sequel, this being for Twisted Pair (2018).

4919.name: The World of Kanako
4919.storyline: Toho Company refused to make this film.

4920.name: Dread
4920.storyline: It took two to five hours per day to put the birthmark make-up on Laura Donnelly for her role as Abby.

4921.name: Infiesto
4921.storyline: The movie title is a real-life location: Infiesto is a small mining town belonging to the municipality of Piloña, in the Principality of Asturias (north-west to Spain). Infiesto is distant about 39 km (24 mi) east to Asturias' capital Oviedo, having a population about 2,400 inhabitants according to census of 2021.

4922.name: White Elephant
4922.storyline: At 51:30, Gabe and his young partner Carlos are outside a movie theater showing a Lee Marvin double feature. Lee Marvin appeared as a hit man with his young partner played by Clu Gulager in The Killers (1964).

4923.name: Compulsion
4923.storyline: Filmed in Palace of Venaria (in italian: Reggia di Venaria), near Turin, Italy. The palace was designed and built from 1675 by Amedeo di Castellamonte, commissioned by duke Charles Emmanuel II of Savoy, who needed a base for his hunting expeditions in the heathy hill country north of Turin.

4924.name: Malik
4924.storyline: Malik's creators originally shot the movie to be released in theaters and had its release date revised several times but finally it was decided to release Malik on Amazon prime.

4925.name: Believer
4925.storyline: Official remake of the Chinese-Hong Kong action thriller Drug War (2012) directed by Johnnie To.

4926.name: Maldoror
4926.storyline: Features Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror (1922)

4927.name: All Ladies Do It
4927.storyline: Feature film debut of model Sejal Shah.

4928.name: The Initiation
4928.storyline: Some of the early scenes at the mental hospital were not actually shot by director Larry Stewart. Peter Crane was originally attached to the film but the production got off to a rough start as shooting fell behind schedule and the budget started to be exceeded. Producers brought in Stewart to replace Crane on the film.

4929.name: Don't Be Afraid of the Dark
4929.storyline: The total production time - including script approval by Lorimar, casting, special effects, voice-overs, and exterior shots - was slightly over two weeks, making this one of the quickest made-for-TV movie turnarounds ever. This was due mainly to a writers strike that began just before the script was completed.

4930.name: The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes
4930.storyline: By the time of filming, Sir Christopher Lee had become famous as Count Dracula. When he and Billy Wilder walked on the shores of Loch Ness at dusk, with bats circling overhead, Wilder said to him, "You must feel quite at home here."

4931.name: The Vault
4931.storyline: Keith Loneker's last movie before he lost his battle with cancer on June 22nd, 2017.

4932.name: The Furies
4932.storyline: At about the 47 minute mark, one of the characters mentions 'the siren' in reference to the sound device keeping them trapped. This could also be a slight nod to the creatures of Greek mythology whose singing lured sailors to their deaths. The title 'The Furies' also references deities from Greek mythology.

4933.name: Blow the Man Down
4933.storyline: The lead singing fisherman is played by David Coffin. This is his first (and only as of Feb 2022) TV or movie appearance. He was cast in this movie because of a viral video of him singing the sea chantey "Roll the Old Chariot" at the 2010 Portsmouth Maritime Folk Festival in Portsmouth, NH.

4934.name: The Bandit
4934.storyline: This movie is exclusively regarded as the savior and the turning point of the Turkish cinema which was desperately struggling against the foreign films since 1980 and having difficulty to attract the domestic audience.

4935.name: Turbo: A Power Rangers Movie
4935.storyline: The first cut had a running time of 3 hours. To this day, none of the deleted footage has surfaced.

4936.name: Charlotte
4936.storyline:
This is the first movie I have seen by Georgia Conlon and it starts off as one type of movie and goes... Well you'll just have to watch and see.The cast is all really good and it's a nice change of pace from the normal CGI fare put about these days.The movie definitely explores some dark themes, and goes in some dark directions but it keeps a good pace throughout and isn't predictable.Georgia is a very talented actress writer and director
I'd really rate this film to anyone who fancies something a bit different to the normal big budget fare from the big studios.Above all an excellent movie about a difficult subject.

4937.name: Law of Desire
4937.storyline: The iconic hose scene was shot twice. The first one wasn't useful because the pressure was so big that Carmen Maura fell down. While the crew adjusted the hose, Maura dried herself and changed the dress. The second time the scene was shot perfectly.

4938.name: The Girl on the Mountain
4938.storyline: The production crew raced against time and barely completed the final shots of the movie just as a forest fire raged to life in the area, barring access to their locations.

4939.name: Absolute Deception
4939.storyline: Brian Trenchard-Smith: as the Police Commissioner.

4940.name: Sky High
4940.storyline: The release was originally planned for August 28 2020. Due the crisis of covid-19 pandemic was postponed several times. For September 2, later without date during some weeks, later for November 27, and a week before the last date, for December 18.

4941.name: Hounds
4941.storyline: "Les meutes" is a dark film (literally, it all happens at night) where everything goes wrong for the main characters, problems pile up and create tension from minute one to the end.It's a very solid movie, with very good performances and good technical aspect too.The visual side of the film doesn't only relies in darkness, strong shadows and red lights to create a very effective gritty, noiry atmosphere, but what I found special is the casting choices, the faces of the actors in this movie deserve a special mention, they give all the character this story needed.In terms of story, I didn't find it to be something special, but the pace and length is good and enough and it entertains.It's overall a good, solid thriller with a refreshing setting due to it's nationality.

4942.name: Fatal Affair
4942.storyline: Nia Long and Omar Epps also worked together in In Too Deep (1999) and Alfie (2004).

4943.name: Murphy's Law
4943.storyline: When there would be delays between takes, Charles Bronson would often get frustrated and could be heard saying "Let's shoot! Let's shoot!" causing the crew to scramble. One reason for this is that family man Charles Bronson liked to go home after shooting each day and have dinner with his family.

4944.name: Trespass
4944.storyline: Walter Hill said of the film, "I wanted to make a down-and-dirty thriller. I wanted to shoot it in a fast, hard style. I wanted to work off the cuff, making it all happen right there."

4945.name: Along With the Gods: The Last 49 Days
4945.storyline: The film is inspired by the Korean Joseon dynasty Buddhist paintings and early Buddhist scriptures of the "Ten Kings of Hell". In the early Buddhism concepts, the Ten Kings of Hell serve as magistrates of each of the ten courts of the underworld to determine the fate of the deceased including the type and severity of punishment and the course of their cycle of rebirth. On the 49th day after death, the soul of the deceased comes before the seventh king and may be reborn, depending on his or her actions in this world.

4946.name: Twist
4946.storyline: The Rotten Tomatoes critics consensus reads "The real Twist in this lunkheaded Dickens update is the involvement of Michael Caine, who hopefully got another terrific house out of it." This is a reference to Jaws: The Revenge (1987), a legendary cinematic turkey for which Sir Michael Caine was paid handsomely. Caine later admitted "I have never seen it [Jaws: The Revenge], but by all accounts it is terrible. However, I have seen the house that it built, and it is terrific."

4947.name: Cargo
4947.storyline: The first feature length science fiction film to be made in Switzerland.

4949.name: Confession
4949.storyline: This movie was filmed in Syracuse NY

4950.name: Eugenie de Sade
4950.storyline: The shooting started early 1970, just after Count Dracula (1970).

4951.name: Billy Bathgate
4951.storyline: Then Disney head Jeffrey Katzenberg opted to produce this gangster epic instead of Warren Beatty's Bugsy (1991) as he figured Beatty's film was too expensive at $40 million. This movie ultimately came in at $50 million, and grossed a mere $15 million during its American release.

4952.name: Suburban Mayhem
4952.storyline: Alice Bell was Emily Barclay's body double for the film. Driving, texting and snorting cornflour instead of speed.

4953.name: House of Usher
4953.storyline: Madeline Usher: Life is nothing but the period between birth and death.

4954.name: Kidnapping Mr. Heineken
4954.storyline: Willem Holleeder (Sam Worthington) went on to become a kingpin in the Dutch underworld, being held responsible for ordering several contract killings, amongst which, the 2003 assassination of his former best friend and co-kidnapper Cor van Hout (Jim Stugess). When the film was released in 2015, Holleeder was in custody awaiting trial for many of those contracts, however, not in relation to the Cor van Hout case. In July 2019, Holleeder was found guilty of five murders and ordered to serve a life sentence.

4955.name: Brother
4955.storyline: This was Takeshi Kitano's only American film he ever made. In an interview, Kitano said that he did not like the final result of Brother and that he regretted his "Hollywood adventure", which was supposed to bring him a wider audience. As a result, Kitano said that he had no intention of filming outside Japan again.

4956.name: Consecration
4956.storyline: Near the beginning of the movie and in a clear nod to the Movie Contact (1997) where Jena Malone starred as Young Ellie, her character Grace walks into her apartment only to reveal that the camera followed her reflection on a mirror, recreating the famous 'mirror effect' of the Robert Zemeckis' film.

4957.name: Dangerous Attraction
4957.storyline: Theatrical trailer for this movie is on "Best Of Italian Movies DVD Volume 1"

4958.name: Vendetta
4958.storyline: Feature film debut of actor Henry Cavill, who was 17 - 18 years old at the time.

4959.name: The California Kid
4959.storyline: Joe Estevez, who played the sailor driving the car (Don McCord), is the real-life younger brother of Martin Sheen, who played Don's brother in the movie.

4960.name: The Apparition
4960.storyline: This film was shot and completed in 2010, but delayed for over two years after Warner Bros. ended its relationship with Dark Castle Entertainment. Warner Bros. gave the film the smallest wide release for a major motion picture in its distribution history.

4962.name: Robot Jox
4962.storyline: The screams of the spectators being crushed by the giant robot were later sampled in the song "The Becoming" by Nine Inch Nails.

4963.name: Fragile
4963.storyline: The "Sleeping Beauty" animated clip is not an excerpt from an animated film, but was created specifically for this movie.

4964.name: Billion Dollar Brain
4964.storyline: The voice of the computer is Donald Sutherland's.

4965.name: Baadshah
4965.storyline: While shooting the opening scene of the film in a club director Abbas Mastan noticed that joyful Jhonny Lever was very depressed on the whole day of the shoot.After the pack up.They went and asked what was the problem he told that his father was had a major operation today and he was nervous all day because of that.Abbas Mastan told him that they could have canceled the shoot if had reported them earlier.Jhonny Lever told them he knew they would cancel the shoot if he had told them but he didn't want to affect the film's schedule.

4966.name: Delta Force 2: The Colombian Connection
4966.storyline: Five crew members were killed in a helicopter accident during filming. The film is dedicated in their memory. They were: Jojo Imperiale (pilot), Geoff Brewer (stuntman/Actor: Maj. Anderson), Gadi Danzig (cameraman), Mike Graham (key grip) & Don Marshall (gaffer).

4968.name: Mother's Day
4968.storyline: The house that was used in this film was an actual house in the woods of Newton, New Jersey. No one had lived in it for 15 years before filming began. The previous owner of the house was actually found to have been murdered there.

4969.name: The Nines
4969.storyline: Melissa McCarthy's role was written specifically with her in mind.

4970.name: Sabotage
4970.storyline: Based on Joseph Conrad's novel "The Secret Agent", this sports a different title, as Sir Alfred Hitchcock's previous movie was called Secret Agent (1936), which was based on stories by W. Somerset Maugham.

4971.name: Firstborn
4971.storyline: Corey Haim's first day of shooting was with Peter Weller, and he went up to compliment the older actor on his performance. Weller collared Haim, throwing him up against a wall to warn him not to speak to him after a take, and it took three assistants to separate them. Haim later admitted that he was terrified by the experience, but Weller apparently was method acting, unaware by anybody else.

4972.name: Encounter
4972.storyline: Riz Ahmed has actively throughout his career sought color-blind casting in his roles so one of the attractive features about this film for him is that the characters' ethnicity doesn't matter with regards to the story.

4973.name: Paparazzi
4973.storyline: It was inspired by Producer Mel Gibson and some celebrities talking about paparazzi nightmares, and Gibson said, "What a great revenge film this would make."

4974.name: The Man with One Red Shoe
4974.storyline: David Ogden Stiers plays the conductor of the symphony orchestra where Richard plays violin. Stiers has worked as a guest conductor with real-life symphony orchestras.

4975.name: Home for Rent
4975.storyline: Home for Rent is a movie that comes out as fresh from the Asian cinema, one that is saturated with ghost stories. Don't get me wrong, this isn't far off either, but it does manage to provide a good plot, non linear execution and plenty of tension and mystery to it.It was a nice surprise, I do declare myself a fan of this genre, the Asian market has its strong points, but lately nothing scary or convincing came out. This one isn't scary either but I do think it's intelligent, respects its viewer and is made with passion instead of a cash grab project.Definitely recommended, it takes its time to build a proper story, to include the viewer, to make him question what's happening on the screen and also offers a good ending. So head to toes, a lovely experience here.Cheers!

4976.name: iSmart Shankar
4976.storyline: Ram Pothineni and Puri Jagannath's first combination

4977.name: Fear and Desire
4977.storyline: Stanley Kubrick later denounced this film as amateurish, saying he considered it like a child's drawing on a fridge.

4978.name: Bloodline
4978.storyline: The part of Elizabeth Roffe was turned down by Candice Bergen, Jacqueline Bisset and Diane Keaton before Audrey Hepburn accepted, and the character's age was changed from 23 to 35.

4979.name: Despite the Falling Snow
4979.storyline: The story of this movie is the book "Before Snow Falls" written by Leyla in "I Can't Think Straight".

4980.name: Farhana
4980.storyline: Well what can I say about Farhana..started off as a slow, ordinary movie and then it zooms off like a rocket! Farhana is story of a housewife who joins a call centre to earn a livelihood. When she moves to a new department which involved romantic chats with strangers, she struggles initially but was saved when she meets Dhaya. The long conversations with Dhaya was poetic and filled with love. As the viewer is lulled into a breezy romance, the story abruptly changes shade into a dark thriller and picks up pace. The event which leads to this change was when Farhana and Dhaya make plans to meet.Loved the way how the director manages to mold the movie into different genres with ease. Kudos to Nelson Venkatesan and his story-telling & direction. Thoroughly enjoyed this movie!

4981.name: Raw Justice
4981.storyline: Pamela Anderson claimed to have had a "Horrible experience" filming the sex scenes, saying "I was thrown around, I was scratched, I was bruised, I was bitten. I cried, I went home, I called my mother.''

4982.name: From Darkness
4982.storyline: No pun intended - I actually should have asked the filmmakers that were there what they did about the shoe issue ... so much snow .. I can only imagine how uncomfortable it must have been during the shooting. But since I do not have an answer for that I'd like to concentrate on the movie, the performances and the cinematography.Though I will add a last thing about the makers not having planned to shoot in snow ... but it happened to have snow where they decided to shoot. Lucky in the end, even if they didn't feel it at the beginning of the shoot. What was there from the start: a concept ... the main character and his issues and point of view ... the viewer is treated as partner to the filmmakers ... they give you something and you are able to make up your own mind ... what happened and how did it happen? So see it through his eyes ... but experience it through other people too ... who is on top of things? I love the ending too ... it may have some minor pacing issues within ... and you may not always agree on character choices ... but suspend your disbelief and go with it ...

4983.name: Night Raiders
4983.storyline: When Danis Goulet's "Night Raiders" opened across Canada in October it set a new record as the widest theatrical opening for an Indigenous film in the country with 80 locations.

4984.name: 24 Hours to Live
4984.storyline: In the beginning beach scene it said Key West, Florida for its location. There are no mountains in the Florida keys.

4986.name: What Josiah Saw
4986.storyline: Robert Patrick and Nick Stahl both appeared in The Terminator franchise.

4987.name: Tomorrow Is Another Day
4987.storyline: According to studio publicity materials for this picture, Steve Cochran broke his leg shooting a fight scene with Hugh Sanders during the first week of filming. After a short hospital stay, he wore a cast for two weeks during this production.

4988.name: The Lioness
4988.storyline: Yes, You Are The VillainBy Distorted Etules

4989.name: Firepower
4989.storyline: Charles Bronson was considered for the role of Jerry Fanon. Rumors had it that Bronson turned this movie down because the producers had refused to write in a role for his wife, Jill Ireland. With much of the pre-production crew already on-location in the Caribbean, Sir Lew Grade wanted to shut down the production when Bronson pulled out. Realizing how much money he had already sunk into a movie that had not properly secured its star actors and actresses, Grade saved face by moving ahead using James Coburn as a replacement for Bronson.

4990.name: Act of Vengeance
4990.storyline: The film was shot under the title "Rape Squad." After American Internation Pictures got cold feet over releasing a film with the word "rape" in the title the title was changed to "Act of Vengeance" shortly before its release. After the film did not do as well as AIP hoped, the film was released as "Rape Squad" in hopes of drumming up some publicity.

4991.name: 13 Cameras
4991.storyline: The landlord rarely, if ever, blinks.

4992.name: The Mephisto Waltz
4992.storyline: Has the singular distinction of being the only theatrical film produced by Twentieth Century-Fox during the entire calendar year of 1970, this due to financial reversals incurred by the studio when several of its recent films failed at the box office.

4994.name: Shadows
4994.storyline: Mia Threapleton is the daughter of Kate Winslet and her first husband, Jim Threapleton.

4995.name: Resurrection
4995.storyline: Actor Christopher Lambert, writer Brad Mirman and director Russell Mulcahy were having a meeting at an LA hotel to discuss another project that they were working on, but the trio couldn't stop talking about "Resurrection" and how much they liked the idea. The three soon abandoned the other film, and quickly decided to make this film.

4997.name: God's Country
4997.storyline: Based on James Lee Burke's short story "Winter Light."

4998.name: The Lift
4998.storyline: Dick Maas was fired halfway through the production because of continuing arguments with producer Matthijs van Heijningen about casting and because Maas insisted that he do the music himself. However, Maas kept on working during that day and was rehired the day after, because Van Heijningen couldn't do it without him.

4999.name: Flight World War II
4999.storyline: The air to ground (land mattress), air to air missiles (R4M), and the Luftwaffe jets actually existed at the time, were being tested, or being built within a couple years of the date the story takes place.

5000.name: Along Came the Devil
5000.storyline: When Pastor John confronts Ashley in the store, she asks him if it is the7D, which is a reference to the Canon DSLR model 7D. She replies that the owns the Mark IV which refers to the similar Canon 5D Mark IV. These were both popular DSLR cameras before Canon moved to mirrorless systems for their professional cameras.

5001.name: Lawnmower Man 2: Beyond Cyberspace
5001.storyline: Austin O'Brien is the only returning cast member from the first film.

5002.name: Strange Circus
5002.storyline: The house the film uses as a set is a real house. Director Sion Sono asked the owners for permission to shoot inside it.

5004.name: The Exterminator
5004.storyline: The Vietnam sequence cost $400,000 to film, which was 20% of the movie's budget of $2 million.

5005.name: The General
5005.storyline: The house of writer and director Sir John Boorman was robbed by the real-life Martin Cahill. Among other things, he stole a gold record that Boorman had on the wall (an award for the "Dueling Banjos" theme from Deliverance (1972)), which inspired Boorman to include that scene in the movie.

5006.name: Section 8
5006.storyline: The photo of Ryan Kwanten's characters father that Mickey Rourke is mourning is a real photo of Joey Rourke, Mickey's brother who died of cancer in 2004

5007.name: Mortal Thoughts
5007.storyline: The James Urbanski role was only a tiny part in the film until Bruce Willis agreed to do the film.

5008.name: Sadak
5008.storyline: An unofficial remake of famous Hollywood flick Taxi driver (1975).

5009.name: Don't Blink
5009.storyline: This is the first film to be directed by Travis Oates who's best known for doing Piglet for Disney's Winnie the Pooh films.

5010.name: He Walked by Night
5010.storyline: Technical advisor for the film was Sgt. Marty Wynn of the Los Angeles Police Dept. During the course of shooting, he fell into conversation with Jack Webb, then the star of radio's "Jeff Regan, Private Investigator", who had a small part in the film. Wynn suggested that Webb do a radio series based on actual police files. Thus was born the idea for "Dragnet," which debuted on NBC radio about four months after this film was released.

5011.name: The Ravine
5011.storyline: Based on a true story about a couple from Olathe, Kansas.

5012.name: What Happened at 625 River Road?
5012.storyline: Well where do I start I could have seen it all the way through if the acting was any good, but it wasn't, so many plot holes you could fit a Boeing 747 in them, I was hoping they would all be murdered. Best acting goes to the cat. I need more words for this review but I really can't think of anything to say, as the boredom and bad acting have numbed my brain but I will endeavour to find one positive thing about the film, oh yes, it's 1 hour 10 minutes long, but I still couldn't bring myself to watch it to the end, my hubby had already picked up his mobile, a sure sign that he couldn't be bothered with it either.

5013.name: After Dark, My Sweet
5013.storyline:
According to Roger Ebert, After Dark, My Sweet "is the movie that eluded audiences; it grossed
less than $3 million, has been almost forgotten, and remains one of the purest and most uncompromising of modern films noir. It captures above all the lonely, exhausted lives of its characters."

5014.name: Operation Seawolf
5014.storyline: All of the internal submarine scenes were filmed inside an actual WW2 Submarine, being the USS Cod The USS COD Submarine Memorial is a National Historic Landmark and is docked in Cleveland, Ohio.

5015.name: Grizzly
5015.storyline: This film became the most financially successful independent film of 1976, earning $39 million worldwide at the box office and breaking several other records. Halloween (1978) broke the record two years later.

5016.name: Naked Souls
5016.storyline: While Pamela Anderson plays only a small role in the plot, much of the advertising and even the movie tagline is focused on her.

5017.name: The Children
5017.storyline: Was nominated for the 2009 Fright Meter Award for Best Horror Movie.

5018.name: Control
5018.storyline: The stunt work at the end of the "railrun" between Bulcsú and Gonzó, when the underground almost hits Gonzó is real, and no special effects were used.

5019.name: Zulu
5019.storyline: In South Africa, the film is titled "City of Violence".

5020.name: Miranda
5020.storyline: First cinema film directed by Marc Munden.

5021.name: 12 Rounds
5021.storyline: For the car chase scenes, John Cena trained with the New Orleans Police Department in order to do his own stunt driving.

5022.name: Night Moves
5022.storyline: Paul Dano and Rooney Mara were considered for the lead roles before Jesse Eisenberg and Dakota Fanning were cast.

5023.name: The Boondock Saints III
5023.storyline: The movie was announced as being officially in production on November 1, 2021, nearly 22 years since the release of The Boondock Saints (1999). It is expected to begin filming in May, 2022.

5024.name: Kubi
5024.storyline: In 2019, Takeshi Kitano released 'Kubi,' a Samurai novel, retelling the events of the 1582 Honno-ji incident, in which the powerful feudal Lord- or Daimyo- Oda Nobunaga was assassinated. It was an idea Kitano first had in the early 1990's, intended as a film. Akira Kurosawa was an advocate for the project, stating that "if Kitano were to make this film, it would be a masterpiece on par with 'Seven Samurai'."In 2021, shooting finally took place, with a release two years later. The result is a sprawling, Shakespearian epic, bloody, thrilling and darkly funny. The film reimagines Nobunaga as a psychopathic ruler, sadistic and unpredictable. He pits the Samurai under him against one other, promising each the throne after he steps down. However, the various clan leaders, such as Hashiba Hideyoshi and Ankokuji Ekei, alongside Samurai general Akechi Mitsuhide, band against him, plotting his downfall.It is a tale that makes for a sweeping, action-filled picture, rocketing along at a brisk pace. The narrative is brimming with volatility, every character out for their own personal gain. There is plenty of back-stabbing- both literally and metaphorically- with betrayal as the dominant theme. Everyone is scheming and plotting; trust is not an easy virtue in Kitano's representation of the Sengoku period, and nothing- even love- gets in the way of self-interest.Kitano demystifies the notion that Samurai were bound by honour, portraying them as vicious killers, with little time for morality. More broadly, he shows how power-structures dictate relationships, as Nobunaga abuses- physically, mentally and sexually- those around him, taking advantage of their subservient position. This mirrors reality, and is a powerful, subtle piece of social commentary. Although perhaps not entirely factually-accurate, Kitano's depiction of the time-period and its characters is compelling and engaging.Furthermore, like most Kitano films, the undercurrent of humour, means that- despite rivers of blood and decapitations galore- it doesn't get too dark. In fact, it is a very funny film, striking a fine balance between comedy, thrills and drama. Moreover, Kitano's characterisation is astute. Every person is distinct, with their own quirks, while the dialogue is sharp and witty. Hashiba Hideyoshi is a particularly risible character, who features in the film's most hilarious scenes.In addition, the action is pulse-pounding and frenetic. Battle scenes are messy and visceral, as they would have been in real life. Katanas sweep through skin, limbs fly, heads roll- it is a gory and riveting affair. Much like his previous 'Zatoichi,' Kitano directs the action magnificently, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats throughout. Moreover, the unpredictable nature of the narrative ensures one doesn't know who will die next, or how; making things all the more exciting.Further, it is a striking looking film. Takeshi Hamada's grittily realistic cinematography is atmospheric and evocative. Much like his sterling work on Yojiro Takita's 'Departures,' his avoidance of flashy stylisations compounds the film's authenticity. He and Kitano shoot the fight scenes expertly, making them appear utterly crazy, while approaching the film as a whole with an artist's eye; some of the images and sequences involved are simply stunning.Moreover, the production design is minutely detailed. Everything looks period-accurate, and Kazuko Kurosawa's costume design is texturally rich and intricate. Additionally, the subtle score from Taro Iwashiro- who worked on Yoichi Sai's 'Blood and Bones,' which also starred Kitano- heightens the film's emotional impact. It is also a well-edited picture, moving at a stallion's pace from the start and never lets up.Part of the reason Kitano waited so long to film 'Kubi' was because he could never get his ideal cast, but, as he explains, when he was "able to gather talented actors in the Kitano-group, and when such excellent actors come together, I felt like it was finally time to make it... and that's how it finally came to fruition." The cast he gathered is vast and noteworthy, which reads like a 'who's who' of premier acting talent.Ryo Kase is chillingly effective as the psychopathic Nobunaga, clearly loving the opportunity to play such a madman. Kenichi Endo does fine work as Araki Murashige, who is the first to rebel against Nobunaga, showcasing a vulnerability that is most affecting. Fans of his work will delight in seeing Kitano's longtime collaborator Susumu Terajima, brilliantly playing Sahei, a ninja, while Nakamura Shido II is most effective in the role of Naniwa Mosuke, a mad peasant who is determined to become a Samurai general, at any cost.Moreover, Nao Omori and Tadanobu Asano do typically excellent work as Hashiba Hidenaga and Kuroda Kanbei, accomplices of Hashiba Hideyoshi, underplaying effectively (as an aside, fans of 'Ichi The Killer' will surely enjoy seeing them on screen together again). Hidetoshi Nishijima brings a steady resolve to the role of Akechi Mitsuhide, and is very believable as one struggling, not just with his love for Murashige, but with the life he's found himself in.
