Finally, Takeshi Kitano, as arch-schemer Hideyoshi- disparagingly nicknamed The Ape- is marvellous, delivering a bewitchingly funny, layered performance that ranks alongside his best.A monumentally entertaining Samurai epic, Takeshi Kitano's 'Kubi' is a gripping story of betrayal and violence. Well-written, funny and thrilling, it's blood-soaked brilliance must be seen to be believed. With striking cinematography, stunning production and costume design and a stirring score, it fires on all cylinders. Boasting excellent performances from all in its star-studded cast, 'Kubi' is, as Akira Kurosawa predicted, a masterpiece.

5025.name: Stolen Baby: The Murder of Heidi Broussard
5025.storyline: This movie was inspired by a true story. It is not a biography.

5026.name: Jana Gana Mana
5026.storyline: When Prithvi Raj is questioning the editor of the newspaper, on the back of the news paper, COVID-19 related incidents are present. Since the movie is taking place in June 2019 COVID would not have existed.

5027.name: The Lady Vanishes
5027.storyline: Though Cybill Shepherd only wears one costume in the movie, (a bias-cut white satin dress), the costume department made nine identical copies to facilitate filming.

5029.name: Race with the Devil
5029.storyline: Jack Starrett replaced original director Lee Frost when Twentieth Century Fox head Alan Ladd Jr. was unsatisfied with the dailies. Most of his footage was re-shot.

5030.name: Quarantine 2: Terminal
5030.storyline: Although the first film of the franchise was a remake of the Spanish film REC (2007), Quarantine 2 has no relation to any of the REC films and has an entirely different plot and setting.

5031.name: War, Inc.
5031.storyline: The tenth movie in which siblings John Cusack and Joan Cusack appeared together.

5032.name: The Black String
5032.storyline: At 51.49 minutes in, Frankie Muniz' character is in an abandoned house, smoking a cigarette. As he sits down, the film clearly runs backwards, as the smoke now goes into the cigarette for roughly a minute.

5033.name: Scorned 2
5033.storyline: Wendy Schumacher filmed this and Fugitive Rage (1996) at the same time.

5034.name: Talk Radio
5034.storyline: Eric Bogosian's play "Talk Radio", on which this film is based, was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize.

5035.name: Escape from Mogadishu
5035.storyline: Official submission of South Korea for the 'Best International Feature Film' category of the 94th Academy Awards in 2022.

5036.name: Wander
5036.storyline: Tommy Lee Jones and Aaron Eckhart have both played the role of Harvey Dent/Two-Face in a Batman movie. Tommy Lee Jones played the role in Batman Forever (1995) and Aaron Eckhart played the role in the The Dark Knight (2008).

5037.name: Great White
5037.storyline: Part of this film was filmed at North Queens Beach on the Redcliffe Peninsula, just north of Brisbane.

5038.name: G.I. Joe: Ever Vigilant
5038.storyline: Dwayne Johnson is interested in reprising his role as Roadblock for the 3rd Film.

5039.name: District 13: Ultimatum
5039.storyline: David Belle didn't practice all his parkour stunts. Most of the ones that you see in the film were of him performing the stunt for the first time.

5040.name: Open Water 3: Cage Dive
5040.storyline: This film (originally shot as 'Into the Deep') was re-branded as part of the Open Water (2003) franchise by the distributor.

5041.name: 22 Bullets
5041.storyline: Both the film and the book it's adapted from are loosely based on a seventies gang war between Jacques Imbert aka "Jacky Le Mat" (considered to be the last "Don" of Marseille) and Tany Zampa. Just like Charly Matteï in the film, Jacky was left for dead on a parking lot with 22 bullets in his body by Zampa, yet miraculously survived with only his right arm remaining paralyzed.

5042.name: Borderland
5042.storyline: Loosely based on actual events which occurred in Mexico in 1989. A group of "narcosatanicos" were discovered to have killed at least 20 people and used their body parts in ritual sacrifices. Cult members lead by Adolfo Constanzo and Sara Aldrete were responsible for the abduction and murder of Mark Kilroy, a Texan pre-med student who disappeared in March 1989 during a spring break in Mexico.

5043.name: Succubus
5043.storyline: Fritz Lang once called it the greatest erotic thriller he'd ever seen.

5044.name: A Thursday
5044.storyline: Neha Dhupia was pregnant in real life during the filming of A Thursday. Thus, the director of the film changed the script to rewrite her character ACP Catherine Alvarez being pregnant.

5045.name: Hell Behind the Bars
5045.storyline: This is the companion film to Detenute violente (1984). Because both films are directed by Gianni Siragusa (as Willy Regan) and feature most of the same cast, they are often confused with each other and believed to be one film. However, they are two entirely different films.

5046.name: Cheat
5046.storyline: I decided to buy this on Google TV in order to better support the Canadian film industry, and I was pleasantly suprised by the story quality! This movie definitely had me second guessing at times and kept me on the edge of my seat with its twists and turns. I felt the production and raid scenes were very well formed out along with certain minor aspects which I've seen bigger films take with. I liken the sensation I got from this film similar to watching When a Stranger Calls and I Know What You Did Last Summer. If you want a new wave psychological guessing game with twists and turns, then check this movie out.

5047.name: Dead of Night
5047.storyline: The first film featuring Tom Savini as a make-up artist.

5048.name: Showgirls 2: Penny's from Heaven
5048.storyline: Some of the stock music used is also used in Birdemic: Shock and Terror (2010).

5050.name: Massacre at Central High
5050.storyline: Reportedly, director Rene Daalder was so upset with the film's musical score that he did not watch his own movie in its entirety for three decades after its release.

5051.name: Bloody Birthday
5051.storyline: Lori Lethin said she liked that she got to do all her own stunts. She said, "I'm kind of an outdoor gal, and also a bit of a tomboy, so the idea of running around, doing my stunts and being chased, was really fun for me."

5052.name: In Too Deep
5052.storyline: According to an interview in 2018 by Omar Epps on the Breakfast Club, the infamous pool stick scene wasn't originally written in the script. LL Cool J brought the idea to the director because he really wanted to show his range as an actor.

5053.name: 24: Redemption
5053.storyline: Events of the film take place between seasons six and seven of the series, and are continued in season seven.

5054.name: Poker Night
5054.storyline: The movie is also known as The Joker.

5055.name: Flood
5055.storyline: Evacuation to a height of over one hundred fifty feet above sea level for London would be to areas of Hampstead in the north, Shooters Hill to the southeast, Biggin Hill to the south, and Richmond Hill to the southwest, all with sea levels double the height of the Thames Barrier, and all within five miles of the Thames. Assuming people casually walk three miles per hour, evacuation by foot would be less than two hours.

5056.name: Double Threat
5056.storyline: Danielle C. Ryan performed all of her own stunts in the film. Not one stunt double for the actress was used.Matthew Lawrence did all of his own driving stunts.

5057.name: Offender
5057.storyline: Joe Cole and Brian Vernel played brothers in Gangs of London (2020).

5058.name: Night and the City
5058.storyline: Director Jules Dassin made the film while in the process of being blacklisted. Fox studio chief Darryl F. Zanuck told him it could possibly be the last film he'd ever direct, so he should shoot the most expensive scenes first so the studio wouldn't be able to blacklist him until it was completed.

5059.name: Joshua Tree
5059.storyline: The Ferrari F40 and Lamborghini Countach in the film are in fact kit cars built on Pontiac Fiero shells. This is especially obvious in any of the interior and profile shots of the F40, which has a much shorter wheelbase than the real one. However, the two cars are over-dubbed with the correct engine notes.

5060.name: Big Driver
5060.storyline: The second film Maria Bello played in a Stephen King adaptation, the first being Secret Window (2004).

5061.name: Cleanskin
5061.storyline: The film's title, "Cleanskin," can have two different meanings. It can either refer to an undercover operative unknown to his intended targets, or it can refer to an extremist who is unknown to the security services, as he or she has had no previous convictions.

5062.name: Child's Play
5062.storyline: Marlon Brando originally signed for the role of Joseph Dobbs (Robert Preston), but quit the production before principal photography commenced. According to Bob Thomas's "Brando: Portrait of the Artist as a Rebel", Brando quit the production when he realized that James Mason had the better role, and that his flagging career would soon be revitalized by the The Godfather (1972). Preston, a fine actor, received poor reviews for his performance from Pauline Kael, among others. Brando subsequently was sued by producer David Merrick.

5063.name: Money Plane
5063.storyline: Writer/director Andrew Lawrence (who also plays Iggy) is the younger brother of Joey Lawrence (The Concierge), and Matthew Lawrence (The Cowboy).

5064.name: Terminator II
5064.storyline: Filmed in late 1988 - early 1989, and shown once at a French film festival in May 1989, but did not go into wide release until August 1990. This was released in many areas outside of the United States with the title "Terminator II", a supposed "sequel" to James Cameron's The Terminator (1984), despite having nothing to do with Cameron's film. Due to rights issues, it wasn't released in the United States until 2018, when Severin Films released the film on DVD and Blu-ray.

5065.name: Miss Bala
5065.storyline: The character of Kiki Camara, the police officer who takes the phone from Laura, is based on Enrique S. "Kiki" Camarena Salazar (1947 - 1985). Camarena was a Mexican-born American agent for the United States Drug Enforcement Administration who was abducted, tortured and murdered whilst on assignment (working undercover) in Mexico.

5066.name: Funeral in Berlin
5066.storyline: Russian soldiers on the east side of the Berlin wall purposely disrupted filming by using mirrors to reflect sunlight into the cameras. The scene where Harry Palmer (Sir Michael Caine) walks to Checkpoint Charlie for the first time had to be filmed from a long distance for that reason.

5067.name: The Independent
5067.storyline: Kathy Bates was originally attached to play the role of presidential candidate, but unable to due to scheduling conflicts. so Ann Dowd was cast instead.

5068.name: Eyes of a Stranger
5068.storyline: Originally conceived and shot as a more straightforward thriller, partway through production it was decided to embrace the then-current slasher genre and introduce more gore and violence.

5069.name: Spartan
5069.storyline: Producer Art Linson and David Mamet were having lunch when Linson informed Mamet that he could not get anything more than a no frills budget for the movie. Val Kilmer was literally at the next table. Linson knew Kilmer and asked him to come over, and they talked about the production. Kilmer was so impressed with the story and Mamet's vision that he agreed to the role giving a significant discount to facilitate Franchise Pictures giving a green-light to the production.

5070.name: The Badge
5070.storyline: For what it's worth, Mona's dead body on the morgue table is a woman's, not a man's. The crests of the iliac, the hip bone, are pronounced, as they are in a woman's pelvic girdle. What this means is that the body was born female and couldn't have been a genotypic male with added breasts, which is the explanation offered by the M.E.

5071.name: Exploited
5071.storyline: MacKenzie Vega's first nude scene. She's the younger sister of Alexa Vega from the Spy Kids films.

5072.name: The Three-Body Problem: I
5072.storyline: The film finished shooting in 2015, but after re-shoots and numerous post-production problems, the film has yet to be released as of 2023.

5073.name: Donnybrook
5073.storyline: The film premiered at TIFF (Toronto international Film Festival) in Canada in September 2018.

5076.name: Survive the Game
5076.storyline: Real life husband and wife Chad Michael Murray and Sarah Roemer star as Eric and Hanna.

5077.name: Wide Sargasso Sea
5077.storyline: The picture was classified and rated with a restricted NC-17 rating in the USA due to its explicit sexual content. Distributor Fine Line Features decided not to appeal the decision in order to try and gain a lower classification rating to make the movie marketable and able for younger audiences to attend. The New York Times reported "Fine Line Features, the art-film division of New Line Cinema, has accepted the rating for 'Wide Sargasso Sea (1993)' which includes male frontal nudity".

5078.name: Horror House
5078.storyline: The film was drastically re-written, re-shot and re-cut by Gerry Levy (under the name Peter Marcus) at the insistence of one of the US producers. Original writer/director Michael Armstrong's commentary on at least one version of the DVD goes into this in detail: "Relatively little of the material outside the house was originally in the film and much of what remains was used differently. None of the material featuring George Sewell was shot by Armstrong and only one scene with Dennis Price [in the nightclub] was his. The motivation of the killer was changed and the relationships between the young people were considerably softened."

5079.name: The Cheap Detective
5079.storyline: The movie was titled "The Cheap Detective", according to screenwriter Neil Simon, "because the detective in those old films never got paid! Who paid Humphrey Bogart for finding all those crooks in The Maltese Falcon (1941)? He arrested Mary Astor and sent her and everyone else to jail. Who paid him? The character is always involved in danger not for the bucks but because it's his lifestyle."

5080.name: The Hater
5080.storyline: The Hater was released on demand (VOD) just twelve days after its theatrical premiere--the very first mainstream Polish production to do so. A few days after its release, cinemas and movie theaters were closed in Poland due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. So the distributor decided to make the movie available on demand.

5081.name: 68 Kill
5081.storyline: Third film that AnnaLynn McCord and Matthew Gray Gubler have started in together, following Excision and Trash Fire.

5082.name: The Spy Gone North
5082.storyline:
Actor Jung-min Hwang, who plays the South Korean spy with the code-name 'Black Venus', said of the emphasis of playing his central spy character of Seok-young Park (aka Suk-young Park) in this film: "I spent a lot of time discussing his character with the director [Jong-bin Yoon], and we decided to approach it
almost like two separate characters, so that the acting for Park Suk-young would be different for
that of 'Black Venus'. For example, when operating in China or North Korea, he is 'Black Venus',
not Park Suk-young. He has his own distinctive look, actions and speaking style. I tried to
portray 'Black Venus' less as a spy, and more as a kind of businessman. In general, 'Black Venus'
and Park Suk-young speak different dialects, the South-eastern Gyeongsang dialect and a
standard dialect, so we can think of them as different people."

5083.name: Rainbow Six
5083.storyline: Michael Jordan will film the origin story of the John Clark character in "Without Remorse" and reprise his character in Rainbow 6. Liev Schrieber and Willem Defoe have played previous incarnations of the John Clark character

5084.name: They're Coming to Get You!
5084.storyline: The clothes that the female cast members wear were provided by fashion houses for free in exchange for their names being listed in the credits.

5085.name: Always Shine
5085.storyline: "It is a woman's birthright to be attractive and charming. In a sense, it is her duty... She is the bowl of flowers on the table of life." -John Robert Powers, Secrets of Poise, Personality and Model Beauty

5086.name: Cheerleader Camp
5086.storyline: The film's original title was "Bloody Pom Poms." This title is still used in various countries such as Germany.

5087.name: Zandalee
5087.storyline: Erika Anderson does not like to remember the filming of the most difficult sequences: "If I think back to the first day of working on Zandalee, I still get goose skin. It was the scene in which Nicolas Cage paints my naked body, the sun and the moon on my breasts and a river that flows down beyond the navel. And since Cage is an actor who loves improvisation, to show the domination of the male over the woman he put in such brutality and such participatory violence, that I was terrified, I felt really violated. We had to stop shooting and do it all again the next day. The rushes were pure pornography, they traumatized me."

5088.name: Roadkill
5088.storyline: The story takes place at the end of summer, but it was filmed in the dead of winter, December/January.

5089.name: Clinical
5089.storyline: Vinessa Shaw (Dr. Jane Mathis) and Aaron Stanford (Miles) had previously starred together in the 2006 movie 'The Hills Have Eyes' as a couple. They played Lynn and Doug respectively.

5090.name: Mothra
5090.storyline: The film was based on a short fantasy novel called "The Luminous Fairies and Mothra" (Hakko Yosei to Mosura). Toho commissioned the story, wanting to appeal to a female audiences since Toho president/producer Iwao Mori found that women made up a large portion of the movie-going public and would often bring people along with them. Writers Takehiko Fukunaga, Shin'ichirô Nakamura, and Yoshie Hotta each wrote part of the original story which was then adapted by screenwriter Shin'ichi Sekizawa into the final film. The film was a hit at the box office and became one of Toho's most successful fantasy films, with Mothra becoming a popular character who would star alongside Godzilla as well has her own film series decades later.

5091.name: Spell
5091.storyline: At about 29 minutes into the run-time there's a shot of a ceramic penguin figurine, a nod to Misery (1990) which features many similar plot points.

5092.name: Macabre
5092.storyline: Contrary to popular belief, Macabre (2009) is not the first Indonesian slasher film. Going back to the 1980s, there was at least a slasher movie inspired by Friday the 13th (1980) called Wolf (1981).

5093.name: Miami Blues
5093.storyline: Gene Hackman at one point was interested in playing Hoke Moseley while Fred Ward initially wanted to portray Frederick J. Frenger Jr.

5094.name: Speed Kills
5094.storyline: In an interview with GQ John Travolta reportedly drank the sea water claiming it made him: "feel alive."

5095.name: The Incubus
5095.storyline: In the recital scene, the song "Vice Versa' is performed by a British band Samson, featuring future Iron Maiden vocalist Bruce Dickinson.

5096.name: Last County
5096.storyline: **Movie Review: Grossly Overrated**I had high expectations for this movie, especially given its impressive rating of 8. However, after watching it, I can only conclude that it deserves no more than a 6.5 at best.The plot was predictable, and the characters were one-dimensional. What should have been a captivating story on paper turned out to be a poorly constructed mess. The acting was mediocre, and the dialogues often felt forced and unrealistic. The cinematography and special effects, which usually have the potential to elevate a film, couldn't compensate for its shortcomings.It is outrageous that they are charging 5 euros for such a poor-quality film on Pathé home. For this price, I expect at least a decently crafted production, something this film utterly fails to deliver. The high rating is completely misplaced and does not reflect reality. It seems something went terribly wrong in the evaluation of this movie, as the end result is simply disappointing.In summary, this movie is not worth watching, and its rating of 8 is absolutely undeserved. Save yourself the effort and the money; this film is not worth your time or the cost.

5097.name: Metamorphosis
5097.storyline: A spirit mimicing Jung-su during the exorcism scene, his amice his seen while talking to Gang-gu. In the next scene when the light color changes, it is gone.

5098.name: The Lovebirds
5098.storyline: Paramount had originally planned to released the film theatrically on April 3, 2020, but decided to release it on Netflix due to the coronavirus pandemic and widespread theatre closings.

5099.name: My Wife's Hidden Lover
5099.storyline: "My Wife's Hidden Lover" (2023) delivers the typical Lifetime movie formula: drama, betrayal, and a twist you might see coming, but not in its entirety. While the movie is definitely watchable, it's plagued by inconsistencies and questionable character choices.The leading lady is far from sympathetic. Her infidelity, and her audacity in moving her lover into the attic of the house her husband paid for, is frustrating to watch. The husband's insistence on her not working is equally perplexing. If she can manage a clandestine affair, why not a secret job? Her constant "I have to go..." pronouncements and confused facial expressions do little to evoke empathy or further the story.The motivation for her supposed commitment to the husband - a promise to build a library using his influence - feels flimsy. The lavish lifestyle she enjoys is a more plausible reason for staying. And her willingness to cheat and so blatantly led me to believe she was looking out for herself and her own ambitions.The plot itself is riddled with holes. The husband's supposed influence with the police was heavily emphasized, yet when the cops arrive, it's the cheating wife holding the gun - a situation that would likely have led to her arrest. The boyfriend's fate at the end is left unclear. And if building a library was so easily achievable, why didn't she just do it herself in the first place? Definitely not an empowering message in this movie.Despite these shortcomings, the movie does manage to deliver a surprising twist--to me anyway. Other viewers said it was predictable, but I didn't see that one coming.One thing tho is that the heroine's happy ending feels unearned, considering her actions, but overall, the movie provides a decent dose of entertainment.

5100.name: Steamboy
5100.storyline: Began production in 1995 and, because of financial problems, it was put on hiatus during 1998. Production companies Production I.G. and Sunrise got involved and brought the movie back in production. A total of eight years was spent on making the movie.

5101.name: Willow Creek
5101.storyline: Bobcat Goldthwait did all the throaty noises for Bigfoot.

5102.name: Extraterrestrial
5102.storyline: In the scene where April (Brittany Allen) is speaking with her father during a Skype call, on her desktop you can see a pirated copy of Grave Encounters (2011), which is the The Vicious Brothers first movie; The Vicious Brothers being the makers of this movie.

5103.name: The Million Dollar Hotel
5103.storyline: Shot entirely within the confines of the eponymous hotel, and the street outside it. This proved slightly problematic with police raids, shoot-outs, and a suicide taking place during filming. The hotel was also infested with rats.

5104.name: A Spy by Nature
5104.storyline: Project notes, plot, and industry news

5105.name: Master
5105.storyline: Kollywood stars Vijay and Vijay Sethupathi work together for the first time in this film.

5106.name: Talaash: The Answer Lies Within
5106.storyline: Aamir Khan learned how to swim for the film, which took him about four months.

5108.name: A Hard Place
5108.storyline: The main portion of the shoot is in Ohio in February 2024 with one final sequence to be shot in Los Angeles in April 2024.

5110.name: Tag
5110.storyline: The music used in the background is the same music in The Walking Dead opening score.

5111.name: Gadar 2
5111.storyline: Film plays a tribute at the opening credits to Amrish Puri and Vivek Shaque.They both can been seen in flash back scenes.A scene shows Amrsih Puri being hanged which was done to CGI effects.

5112.name: Tiger House
5112.storyline: The flag in Mark's window is the national flag of Trinidad and Tobago.

5113.name: The Business
5113.storyline: The DVD features an alternate ending where Frankie meets Carly at the border. There she promptly tells the border guard where to find drugs in Frankie's car.

5114.name: Stranger Eyes
5114.storyline: Taiwanese movie scene is among the very best in Asia, but this movie is a true jewel! Must. Great acting, excellent directing, original storyline keeping you stuck in your seat for 2 hours, groundbreaking ending,... well, a likely award winning movie.Siew Hua Yeo offered us a masterpiece 6 years ago with A Land Imagined, but with Stranger eyes, he is reaching new heights! Fran Borgia and Stefano Centini have this magic gift to always produce what's best in the Asian cinema industry. Another great project well delivered! Lead actors Chien Ho Wu and Kang Sheng Lee are just fitting very well in this twisted plot! Great work! I loved it!

5115.name: No Man's Land
5115.storyline: Brad Pitt, as a fancy party waiter with a mullet hairdo, can be seen very clearly the second after Charlie Sheen says, "Welcome to the lifestyles of the rich and aimless." He's in the middle of the room and then walks off-screen to the left.

5116.name: Red Dot
5116.storyline: This is the first Netflix original film from Sweden.

5117.name: White Orchid
5117.storyline: Both Olivia Thirlby & Rachel Taylor starred in another movie . . . The Darkest Hour.

5119.name: Gaslight
5119.storyline: Sara Ali Khan went to acting school in the U.S. after shooting this movie. She was advised by her father to learn how to express and emote better and improve her acting skills for her future horror movies.

5120.name: The Day
5120.storyline: All the principal cast members helped design their own clothes. For example, Ashley Bell came up with the knee and elbow pads that Mary wears in the movie.

5121.name: The Machine Girl
5121.storyline: According to writer and director Noburo Iguchi, the idea for The Machine Girl went back to a simple idea he had about a one-armed girl in a bikini looking for revenge. The idea for the machine gun arm came later.

5123.name: Amber Alert
5123.storyline: Remade by the same team in 2024.

5124.name: Pieta
5124.storyline: According to director Kim Ki-duk this film was prepared in 10 days, shot in 20 days on location and post-produced in 30 days.

5125.name: Man on Wire
5125.storyline: Low on money for the Sydney Harbor Bridge walk, Philippe Petit got the cable in exchange for an impromptu juggling and magic show he put on for employees.

5126.storyline: During the 2018 floods in Kerala, several individuals and organizations came forward to provide assistance. One notable instance was when a group of fishermen, who are skilled in navigating rough waters, turned into heroes by using their boats to rescue stranded people and deliver supplies to remote areas. Their selfless efforts earned them the nickname "Kerala's Own Navy" and demonstrated the power of community resilience during times of crisis.

5127.name: Deported Women of the SS Special Section
5127.storyline: The film was refused a UK cinema certificate in 1977 by the BBFC.

5128.name: Karen
5128.storyline: The title role was written with Candace Cameron Bure in mind. Bure turned down the part due to scheduling conflicts, though she was allegedly flattered. Taryn Manning was eventually cast, and earned a Razzie nomination for her performance.

5129.name: ATM
5129.storyline: The killer is wearing exactly the same outfit as the killer from Urban Legend (1998).

5130.name: The Believers
5130.storyline: Gary Farmer: seen briefly at the start as a furniture removal man.

5131.name: Right at Your Door
5131.storyline: The film was acquired by Lions Gate at 2006 Sundance for nearly $3 million for worldwide rights.

5132.name: Above Suspicion
5132.storyline: Christopher Reeve's character uses a wheelchair due to paralysis. On May 27, 1995, six days after the film aired, Reeve broke his neck in a horse riding accident, leaving him paralyzed for the rest of his life.

5133.name: Pyewacket
5133.storyline: The name "Pyewacket" comes from the 1647 British pamphlet "The Discovery of Witches," in which author Matthew Hopkins claims to have interrogated witches in Essex County. One witch names many familiars, including the spirit Pyewacket which appeared to her as some sort of animal.

5134.name: Freeway II: Confessions of a Trickbaby
5134.storyline: The film suffered 17 cuts/trims before being granted an R-rating by the MPAA.

5135.name: The Naked Runner
5135.storyline: While filming None But the Brave (1965), Brad Dexter had apparently rescued Frank Sinatra when he got into difficulty swimming. As a thank you, Sinatra agreed to star in this when Dexter was starting out as a producer.

5136.name: The Reincarnation of Peter Proud
5136.storyline: Margot Kidder is about six months younger than Jennifer O'Neill in real life, yet she played Miss O'Neill's character's mother in this film.

5137.name: Cold Comes the Night
5137.storyline: Sophia's pet Mr. Jones is a red-eared slider, a very common species in North America. He is listed in the credits (in the Stunts department) as HHH Duck - his real name is 'Horny Horny Horny Duck'.

5138.name: The Order
5138.storyline: Heath Ledger, Shannyn Sossamon, Mark Addy, and Leagh Conwell all previously appeared together in A Knight's Tale (2001). Both movies written and directed by Brian Helgeland.

5139.name: Mission Majnu
5139.storyline: Mission Majnu was an actual debut for actress Rashmika Mandanna in Hindi films. However, as the film faced numerous delays, Goodbye (2022) had became her Bollywood debut.

5140.name: May God Save Us
5140.storyline: Most of the interior scenes (the houses and the police station) were shot in Tenerife because of the tax advantages that exist in the Canary Islands.

5141.name: Salawahan
5141.storyline: New LovePerformed by Ben MaraWritten, arranged and produced by Ben Mara

5142.name: All Hallows Eve Trickster
5142.storyline: Kevin O'Neil (segment: PrettyFace): Detective describing the scene says, "Multiple stab wounds, escaped in makeup." ?

5144.name: Hell Drivers
5144.storyline: Although Stanley Baker had played major supporting roles in movies to great acclaim for several years, this was the first time he played the leading role in a movie.

5145.name: The Good German
5145.storyline: The film was shot as if it had been made in 1945. Only studio back lots, sets and local Los Angeles locations were used. No radio microphones were used, the film was lit with only incandescent lights and period lenses were used on the cameras. The actors were directed to perform in a presentational, stage style. The only allowance was the inclusion of nudity, violence and cursing which would have been forbidden by the Production Code.

5146.name: The Loneliest Planet
5146.storyline: The book passage that is read out is from "A Hero of Our Time" by Mikhail Lermontov.

5147.name: The Blue Gardenia
5147.storyline: Director Fritz Lang and cinematographer Nicholas Musuraca developed a revolutionary dolly for the camera that allowed for sustained tracking shots and intimate close-ups while shooting this film. Lang preferred the practice of tracking into a close-up shot of an actor as opposed to cutting to a close-up in editing. He believed the tracking close-up captured more of the actors' intimacy and emotions.

5148.name: The Cured
5148.storyline: Some of the scenes were filmed in the old Belfast victorian prison called the Crumlin Road Jail.

5149.name: Megalodon
5149.storyline: Exterior ship scenes were filmed on the SS Lane Victory, a WWII-era ship and nautical museum docked in San Pedro, CA.

5150.name: Boy Undone
5150.storyline: Filming took one year and the script was enhanced meanwhile the film was shot.

5151.name: Someone's Watching Me!
5151.storyline: For more than two decades, the movie was almost better known as the "lost Carpenter film" due to its scarce availability on home video. Contrary to many countries in Europe where the movie actually got released on VHS, there has never been an official VHS release in America. Warner Bros. finally released it on DVD in 2007.

5152.name: Quicksilver
5152.storyline: Kevin Bacon met several bike messengers himself. Bacon said: "You can make your own schedule, and you can work hard and make more money, or work less and make less money. You're really your own boss. Most messengers are on their way to some place else. Some of them are college kids, and some are actors. Some of them are serious cyclists who want to race and they figure this is the best kind of work they can get because they're constantly training, but others are doing it because it's what they do for a living. Even though the guys may be eclectic, there is a strong sense of commitment". Producer Daniel Melnick said: "The actual bike messengers have one thing in common: problems with authority. They gravitate to this job because they can be their own bosses. No one is dependent on them but themselves". Director Thomas Michael Donnelly said of Bacon's character that Jack Casey "is a survivor on a very basic level. He returns to a more primitive tribal world to regain his spirit. Only then will he be able, if he wants, to return to a more mechanized, intellectual world". All these three key production personnel of Bacon, Melnick, and Donnelly, all had a strong sense of the origin of the film's story and character.

5153.name: Mesrine: Public Enemy No. 1
5153.storyline: The filming of this and Mesrine: Killer Instinct (2008), which lasted nine straight months, was done in reverse chronological order so that Vincent Cassel could progressively lose the weight he gained in preparation of the role, as Cassel knew he couldn't gain weight while filming.

5154.name: The January Man
5154.storyline: Director Pat O'Connor and actress Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio met while working on this project and were later married in 1990.

5155.name: The Killer with No Name
5155.storyline: The lead actress couldn't act her way out of a paper bag, nothing about her acting was convincing. It was very distracting while trying to get into the movie. Most of the other actors weren't that great either, it felt like we were watching a high school production at times. I wouldn't recommend any movie this actress is in, my friends and I kept giggling at her lack of acting abilities. She couldn't cry, act sad, shocked or happy. Just terrible! I only finished the movie to see how it went off. I should have skipped to the last 20 minutes. I created an account just to leave this review so I could warn others. Lol.

5156.name: Pumpkinhead II: Blood Wings
5156.storyline: Judge Dixon's house is the same location used in Motel Hell (1980).

5157.name: Knock Off
5157.storyline: Hong Kong superstar and director Sammo Kam-Bo Hung served as the film's 2nd unit director. The release print of "Knock Off" suffers from the removal of a lot of the martial arts action shot for the film, with a couple of sequences being very heavily edited. The final battle between Jean-Claude Van Damme's character and Australian actor/stuntman Michael Miller is less than half of the action shot for their fight, and upon careful viewing you can pick up the fact that the fight has raged across several different sections on the boat, while the fight between Jeff Wolfe's character Scar and Jean-Claude's is the most heavily edited with more of the action being shown in the "Making Of" featured on several of the DVD editions than in the finished film.

5158.name: The Retaliators
5158.storyline: The members of Five Finger Death Punch demanded to eat Filet Mignon for lunch every day or they would not work.

5159.name: Witchboard
5159.storyline: The house in the film was also used in Waxwork (1988) and Willard (1971). This Los Angeles home has since been "retired" as a filming location.

5160.name: Point Blank
5160.storyline: The movie that Big D is watching when Abe and Paul enter his house is To Live and Die in L.A. (1985), directed by William Friedkin. Later, when they're waiting for supplies, the movie they're watching is Sorcerer (1977), also directed by Friedkin.

5161.name: Breaking In
5161.storyline: The opening scene with Isaac being hit by the car was a late addition to the script.

5162.name: Godzilla vs. King Ghidorah
5162.storyline: This became one of the most controversial Godzilla movies. Shortly after the film's release in Japan, CNN ran a lengthy story about the film being anti-American, showing the scenes of the US soldiers being killed and the plot featuring Westerners antagonists being debated. The original Godzilla director, Ishirô Honda, was also critical of Kazuki Ômori's choices, stating he had gone too far. Omori, defended his artistic decision on camera, arguing that the film was not meant to be anti-American stating," "The movie is not especially anti-U.S., I just thought I'd try to picture the identity of the Japanese people." Economic tensions between East and West were high at this time, and the negative publicity was very much a sign of the times.

5163.name: Both Sides of the Blade
5163.storyline: First film of actor Hana Magimel, daughter of Juliette Binoche and Benoît Magimel.

5164.name: Losing Control
5164.storyline: At the bank scene, a crew member is visible besides the car door. He quickly disappear in the next shot, when the main characters leave the bank's parking spot.

5165.name: Top Sensation
5165.storyline: The film was refused a UK theatrical certificate in 1970. It was finally passed fully uncut for DVD in 2016.

5166.name: Kidnapped
5166.storyline: The movie is composed by 12 long shots, without cuts in them.

5167.name: Reservation Road
5167.storyline: Mark Ruffalo was originally cast in Signs (2002), but left the film prior to shooting due to the discovery of a brain tumor. Ruffalo dreamt he contracted the tumor during shooting of Signs, which provoked him to visit a doctor. The tumor was benign, but Ruffalo took nearly a year to recover and lost hearing in his left ear. Production of Signs moved forward, and Joaquin Phoenix took Ruffalo's spot.

5168.name: Extremities
5168.storyline: Interviews with Farrah Fawcett stated that during filming they really slapped each other just like they did on stage to simulate reality. Also, in the source off-Broadway stage production, they had to have guards on hand because the violence would be so real audience members would try to jump up on stage and help Fawcett.

5169.name: Killer Sofa
5169.storyline: The image of the bloodied reclining chair with long fangs which appears on posters and disc box art does not actually appear in a scene in the movie.

5170.name: Gymkata
5170.storyline: The film debut of Kurt Thomas, a former Olympic gymnast and his only starring role in his career.

5171.name: Deadtime Stories
5171.storyline: Some of the more explicit gore in the first segment had to be toned down in order to secure an R rating from the MPAA.

5173.name: Fabricated City
5173.storyline: I recommend only watching this movie if you can find it on DVD, or if it's available on a streaming service somewhere.I watched this online and the English subtitles were very poor, a lot of grammatical / spelling errors that didn't even make sense half the time and a lot of the scenes didn't even have subtitles at all which was very disappointing.Still really enjoyed the movie regardless.

5174.name: Husk
5174.storyline: In the 2005 short that this film is based on, the writer and director of this film ( Brett Simmons ) plays the character of Brian.

5175.name: Silver and the Book of Dreams
5175.storyline: Normally I like a taut 90 minute-ish film, but I could have done with this being a bit longer. There's little to no characterisation, making it hard to understand the villains' motivations, or root for the good guys. I had more questions than answers about the mechanics of the dream world at the end too. Tonally it's odd as well - at first I thought it was a kids' film, but there's loads of effing and jeffing. Also, all the 'kids' have tattoos - what's happening there? (Or maybe I just got old.) It does have some very pretty visuals, but that's about the only thing I enjoyed. It just didn't come together for me.

5176.name: Last Night on Earth
5176.storyline: It was a great movie and gave us something to think about. What lengths would you go to how would you get there? And who could you turn to?The movie was filmed in the Tennessee mountains. As good a region to film this as it gets. It had all the elements needed to for the perfect backdrop. The movie was chilling and truthful. Poignant. The main characters had the full attention of the audience. I will see it again. Great job!The Q&A after the screening offered behind the scenes explanations, not that they would needed, but was something extra that gave us insight to the creation of the movie.and the sculpting of the characters.

5177.name: Detour
5177.storyline: Early in the movie Harper James (Tye Sheridan) is watching an old black and white movie whilst laying on the couch. You see a couple driving down the highway. That scene is from the movie Detour (1945) starring Tom Neal and Ann Savage.

5178.name: The Last Sentinel
5178.storyline: The deserted city street scenes were filmed in two days in the back lot at Universal Studios.

5179.name: Mikey
5179.storyline: One of very few films banned in the UK, but not the Republic of Ireland.

5180.name: A Mother's Nightmare
5180.storyline: Grant Gustin (Chris Stewart) and Jessica Lowndes (Vanessa Redlynn) both starred in 90210.

5181.name: Immortal
5181.storyline: Was one of several films around the world that were the first to use an entirely "digital backlot" (i.e. the actors were all shot in front of blue- and green-screens with all the backgrounds added in post-production, a technique which has been used for TV, video and video game production for many years). Fans debate on which movie was shot first, but the other movies include: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004), Casshern (2004), and Sin City (2005).

5182.name: Four Flies on Grey Velvet
5182.storyline: Dario Argento's usual collaborator Ennio Morricone scored the film, but had a major argument with Argento over some tracks Argento didn't want in it. As a result, the director and Morricone would not work together again until 1996, and the rock group Goblin would eventually become Argento's regular composers.

5183.name: The Night Digger
5183.storyline: The film's original length was 110 minutes. Bernard Herrmann composed his score for a 110-minute version; however, about 13 minutes was cut right before the film's official release. So some of Herrmann's cues didn't end up in the film. In the released version (97-98 minutes), small portions of Herrmann's cue close to the end accidentally were edited out. Some of the cues Herrmann composed for the released version didn't end up in the released cut. One of those was a cue for when the nurse walks back and enters her car.

5184.name: The Psychic
5184.storyline: Unusually for an Italian film of the time, all the actors spoke their dialogue in English regardless of nationality, instead of being overdubbed in the English soundtrack. The Italian track however is dubbed by other actors voicing the characters, even the film's Italian actors.

5186.name: Our Man in Havana
5186.storyline: Fidel Castro's government gave permission for this movie, which presents the fallen regime of Fulgencio Batista in an unflattering light, and also condemns American and British meddling, to shoot on-location in Havana, only a few months after the revolution. It was completed during the brief period in 1959 before Cuba had aligned itself with the Soviet Union.

5187.name: Ferry
5187.storyline: Frank Lammers had to lose weight because he is playing a younger Ferry and had to look more fit.

5188.name: Storm Warning
5188.storyline: Everett De Roche initially wrote the script thirty years prior to the movie's production.

5189.name: Extraction
5189.storyline: Bruce Willis filmed all his scenes in a single day.

5190.name: Emanuelle Around the World
5190.storyline: Laura Gemser said that in every film she made with director Joe D'Amato, he tried many times to make her film hardcore porn scenes, but she always gave him a resounding "No!."

5191.name: Blacula
5191.storyline: The film was popular in the U.S., debuting at #24 on "Variety"'s list of top films. It eventually grossed over $1 million, making it one of the highest grossing films of 1972.

5192.name: Surveillance
5192.storyline: The song during the roll of end credits is sung by the director's father, David Lynch ('Speed Roaster').

5193.name: The Babysitter
5193.storyline: Alicia Silverstone is rumoured to have turned down the part in this film on numerous occasions. She finally agreed after her nude scenes were removed.

5194.name: Yashoda
5194.storyline: In one scene Yashoda discusses with other housemates the absence of tracking of time, as if the facility ensures not providing the date or time details to all in-house pregnant ladies, but on her second visit to ultrasound, the doctor shows her imaging monitor which does carry date/time stamp.

5195.name: The Lazarus Project
5195.storyline: Paul Walker was the first choice for the lead role in the film.

5196.name: Piercing
5196.storyline: It was based on the 1994 Japanese novel "Piercing" by Ryû Murakami.

5197.name: The Stendhal Syndrome
5197.storyline: The opening scene was shot inside the famous Uffizi Gallery in Florence. As of 2014, Dario Argento is the only director who's ever received permission to film inside the museum.

5198.name: Nekrotronic
5198.storyline: David Wenham's last scene in the film was difficult for him because he is a bit claustrophobic, but according to the director he powered through it like a trouper.

5199.name: Once Upon a Time in Hollyweird
5199.storyline: Cillian Murphy, David Carradine, Roy Scheider and Harvey Keitel only appear via archival footage of the unreleased movie, "Red Light Runners", filmed in 2003.
